Crunch","desc":"Exclusive articles, conference calls, no banner ads, and more.","url":"\/subscribe\/?tpcc=rightrailmay19","button_text":"Try it free"},"live_event":"0","livestream_hash":null,"feature_islands":{"homepage":[{"id":1989998,"date":"2020-05-18T00:10:18","date_gmt":"2020-05-18T07:10:18","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=1989998"},"modified":"2020-05-18T00:10:18","modified_gmt":"2020-05-18T07:10:18","slug":"tsmc-reportedly-stops-taking-orders-from-huawei-after-new-u-s-export-controls","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/05\/18\/tsmc-reportedly-stops-taking-orders-from-huawei-after-new-u-s-export-controls\/","title":{"rendered":"TSMC reportedly stops taking orders from Huawei after new U.S. export controls"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><a href=\"https:\/\/www.tsmc.com\/english\/default.htm\">Taiwanese Semiconductor Manufacturing Co.<\/a>, the world\u2019s largest contract semiconductor maker, has stopped taking new orders from <a href=\"https:\/\/www.huawei.com\/en\/\">Huawei Technologies<\/a>, one of its largest customers, according to the <a href=\"https:\/\/asia.nikkei.com\/Spotlight\/Huawei-crackdown\/TSMC-halts-new-Huawei-orders-after-US-tightens-restrictions\">Nikkei Asian Review<\/a>. <span style=\"font-size: 1.125rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\">The report said the decision was made to comply with new <\/span><a style=\"background-color: #ffffff; font-size: 1.125rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\" href=\"https:\/\/www.commerce.gov\/news\/press-releases\/2020\/05\/commerce-addresses-huaweis-efforts-undermine-entity-list-restricts\">United States export controls<\/a><span style=\"font-size: 1.125rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\">, announced last Friday, that are meant to make it more difficult for Huawei to obtain chips produced using U.S. technology, including manufacturing equipment.<\/span><\/p>\n<p>Orders taken before the ban or already in production will not be affected, if they can ship before September 14. Huawei, the world\u2019s largest telecom equipment maker, is TSMC\u2019s second-biggest customer after Apple. TSMC makes many of the advanced chips used by Huawei, including in its smartphones.<\/p>\n<p>The U.S. Commerce Department released its new orders on Friday, which specifically target Huawei by making it harder for the company to create chips using U.S. software and technology, even in foundries located abroad.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>On the same day as the Commerce Department&#8217;s announcement, TSMC said that it is opening a new $12 billion advanced chip foundry in Arizona with support from the state and the U.S. federal government. Once opened, the plant will allow more of TSMC\u2019s American clients to fabricate their chips domestically.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"K8EjPLm8av\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/05\/14\/tsmc-to-build-a-12-billion-advanced-semiconductor-plant-in-arizona-with-u-s-government-support\/\">TSMC to build a $12 billion advanced semiconductor plant in Arizona with US government support<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe title=\"&#8220;TSMC to build a $12 billion advanced semiconductor plant in Arizona with US government support&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/05\/14\/tsmc-to-build-a-12-billion-advanced-semiconductor-plant-in-arizona-with-u-s-government-support\/embed\/#?secret=K8EjPLm8av\" data-secret=\"K8EjPLm8av\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p>TSMC\u2019s announcement came after <a href=\"https:\/\/www.wsj.com\/articles\/trump-and-chip-makers-including-intel-seek-semiconductor-self-sufficiency-11589103002?mod=hp_lead_pos5\">the Wall Street Journal reported<\/a> that White House officials were in discussions with TSMC and Intel to build foundries in the U.S. in order to reduce reliance on factories in Asia and the international supply chain.<\/p>\n<p>In an email, a TSMC representative told TechCrunch that the company does not disclose customers&#8217; order details. She added that TSMC complies with laws and applicable regulations, and is &#8220;following the U.S. export rule change closely&#8221; and &#8220;working closely with outside counsels to conduct legal analysis and ensure a comprehensive examination and interpretation of these rules.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>This is the latest restriction the U.S. government has leveled against Huawei citing national security concerns. Along with ZTE, Huawei was <a href=\"https:\/\/www.nytimes.com\/2012\/10\/09\/us\/us-panel-calls-huawei-and-zte-national-security-threat.html\">identified as a potential threat<\/a> to security by the House Intelligence Committee in 2012.<\/p>\n<p>&nbsp;<\/p>\n<p>The two companies have denied the charges, but under the Trump administration, the U.S government\u2019s efforts to stop both from doing business with U.S. companies has intensified. According to the Nikkei Asian Review report, Huawei anticipated the Commerce Department\u2019s new orders and has been building a year\u2019s worth inventory of chips needed for its telecom equipment.<\/p>\n<p>TechCrunch has contacted Huawei for comment.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"1KkzN6NI2e\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/05\/15\/u-s-china-trade-enters-new-era-after-overnight-huawei-foxconn-and-tsmc-announcements\/\">US-China trade enters new era after overnight Huawei, Foxconn and TSMC announcements<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe title=\"&#8220;US-China trade enters new era after overnight Huawei, Foxconn and TSMC announcements&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/05\/15\/u-s-china-trade-enters-new-era-after-overnight-huawei-foxconn-and-tsmc-announcements\/embed\/#?secret=1KkzN6NI2e\" data-secret=\"1KkzN6NI2e\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Taiwanese Semiconductor Manufacturing Co., the world\u2019s largest contract semiconductor maker, has stopped taking new orders from Huawei Technologies, one of its largest customers, according to the Nikkei Asian Review. The report said the decision was made to comply with new United States export controls, announced last Friday, that are meant to make it more difficult [&hellip;]<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":4330449,"featured_media":1990000,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"outcome":"","status":"","crunchbase_tag":0,"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"2d2e8c97-2de3-33c0-9d53-8f8358cefd52"},"categories":[17396],"tags":[376594,284207,289167,448312953],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_event":[],"jetpack_featured_media_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/GettyImages-1126455184.jpg","shortlink":"https:\/\/tcrn.ch\/3dSSQba","rapidData":{"pt":"","pct":""},"featured":false,"subtitle":"","fundingRound":false,"seoTitle":"","seoDescription":"","premiumContent":false,"premiumCutoffPercent":1,"tc_cb_mapping":[{"slug":"huawei-technologies","cb_name":"Huawei The French government has decided to limit the deployment of telecom equipment belonging to the Chinese group, Huawei. Westerners suspect Huawei of using it\u2019s position in the global market for espionage purposes. In the USA, Huawei is targeted by more than 20 counts. The tense relations between Huawei and the United States finally led to complaint being filed against the Chinese manufacturer, accusing it of technology theft and sanction violations. Huawei Technologies Co. Ltd. is a company founded in 1987, headquartered in Shenzhen, China, which provides solutions in the field of information and communication technologies. Department of Commerce","slug":"u-s-department-of-commerce","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/448312953"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=448312953"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=448312953"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=448312953"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=448312953"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[]]}},{"id":1990008,"date":"2020-05-18T00:45:40","date_gmt":"2020-05-18T07:45:40","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=1990008"},"modified":"2020-05-18T01:44:55","modified_gmt":"2020-05-18T08:44:55","slug":"indias-swiggy-to-cut-1100-jobs-scale-down-cloud-kitchen-operations","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/05\/18\/indias-swiggy-to-cut-1100-jobs-scale-down-cloud-kitchen-operations\/","title":{"rendered":"India&#8217;s Swiggy to cut 1,100 jobs, scale down cloud kitchen operations"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><a class=\"crunchbase-link\" href=\"https:\/\/crunchbase.com\/organization\/swiggy\" target=\"_blank\" data-type=\"organization\" data-entity=\"swiggy\">Swiggy <span class=\"crunchbase-tooltip-indicator\"><\/span><\/a> said on Monday it is cutting 1,100 jobs and scaling down some adjacent businesses as India\u2019s top food delivery startup looks to reduce costs to survive the coronavirus pandemic that has made people cautious about ordering food online.<\/p>\n<p>In an internal email, which the Bangalore-headquartered startup <a href=\"https:\/\/blog.swiggy.com\/news-updates\/changes-were-making-to-adapt-to-the-times\">published<\/a> on its blog, Swiggy co-founder and chief executive Sriharsha Majety said the startup\u2019s core food business had been \u2018severely impacted.\u2019<\/p>\n<p>The startup, which employed about 8,000 people late last year, is currently processing fewer than a million orders a day on its platform, down from nearly 3 million it was handling before the outbreak, people familiar with the matter told TechCrunch.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>To cut costs, Swiggy said it would be eliminating 1,100 jobs \u201cacross grades and functions in the cities and head office&#8221; over the next few days. The company, backed by Prosus Ventures, said it will provide those affected with three months of salary, with one additional month for each year they have spent at the startup.<\/p>\n<p>It will also provide those being let go with medical and accident coverage until the end of the year, and counseling for mental, emotional, and financial stress throughout the same period.<\/p>\n<p>\u201cThis is easily the hardest and longest deliberated decision the management team and I have been faced with over recent times. We have been fortunate to have some of the brightest missionary talent in the country join us over the last few years, and I would like to state unequivocally that this is not at all a reflection of anyone\u2019s performance,\u201d wrote Majety.<\/p>\n<p>TechCrunch, as well as Indian newspaper Economic Times and outlet Entrackr, reported in late April that the startup was<a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/04\/21\/indian-food-delivery-startup-swiggy-is-cutting-jobs\/\"> cutting about 1,000 jobs<\/a>, mostly in the cloud kitchen category. Swiggy had confirmed the layoff at the time, but did not share a number.<\/p>\n<p>A Swiggy spokesperson did not immediately share whether today\u2019s announcement represents the same job cuts. A person familiar with the matter told TechCrunch today that Monday&#8217;s 1,100 job cuts primarily affect those in non-cloud kitchen parts of the business.<\/p>\n<p>Monday\u2019s announcement follows a similar move by <a class=\"crunchbase-link\" href=\"https:\/\/crunchbase.com\/organization\/zomato\" target=\"_blank\" data-type=\"organization\" data-entity=\"zomato\">Zomato, <span class=\"crunchbase-tooltip-indicator\"><\/span><\/a> the No. 2 food delivery startup in India which said last week it was <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/05\/15\/indian-food-delivery-startup-zomato-cuts-13-of-workforce\/\">reducing its global workforce by 13%, or about 520 people<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p>Swiggy&#8217;s Majety said the company was &#8220;choosing to scale down or shut down\u00a0adjacent businesses that are either going to be highly volatile or will not be highly relevant for the next 18 months.&#8221; One of those businesses is cloud kitchens &#8212; an area Swiggy has focused on for more than two years, and seemingly\u00a0<a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2019\/11\/19\/swiggy-cloud-kitchen-india\/\">doubled down just last quarter<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p>Late last year, Swiggy executives said they had established 1,000 cloud kitchens for its restaurant partners in the country \u2014 more than any of its local rivals. The startup said it had invested in more than a million square feet of real estate space across 14 cities in the country in the last two years.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;Since the onset of Covid, we have already begun the process of shutting down our kitchen facilities temporarily or permanently, depending on their outlook and profitability profile. We are already operating at significantly lower levels on our staffing and physical infra than our earlier footprint, and will continue to optimize before we get more clarity on order volumes for food delivery,&#8221; wrote Majety.<\/p>\n<p>Swiggy and Zomato, that have formed duopoly in India&#8217;s food delivery business, are currently in talks to <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/04\/06\/indias-swiggy-raises-43m-to-expand-to-new-businesses\/\">raise additional capital<\/a> as part of their ongoing financing rounds. In recent weeks they have also started to deliver grocery items to spur demand.<\/p>\n<p>Several industries, especially travel and hospitality, have also been severely hit as people follow the New Delhi&#8217;s stay-at-home order. Oyo, a startup valued at $10 billion, said last month it was <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/04\/08\/indias-oyo-furloughs-thousands-of-employees-as-revenue-drops-by-over-50\/\">placing thousands of employees on leave and furloughs for up to three months<\/a> in the U.S. and several other markets as its revenue dropped by more than 60% in recent months.<\/p>\n<p>Ixigo, a 13-year-old travel and hotel booking service, said late April it was <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/03\/30\/ixigo-cuts-salary-of-every-employee-over-coronavirus\/\">cutting the salary of its entire staff.<\/a> MakeMyTrip, another travel and stay booking service, announced in the same month that it was also cutting the salary of its top management level across the company. This week, MakeMyTrip announced it was entering the food delivery business.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Swiggy said on Monday it is cutting 1,100 jobs and scaling down some adjacent businesses as India\u2019s top food delivery startup looks to reduce costs to survive the coronavirus pandemic that has made people cautious about ordering food online. In an internal email, which the Bangalore-headquartered startup published on its blog, Swiggy co-founder and chief Crunch Live: Join Revolution&#8217;s Steve Case and Clara Sieg on May 21 at 3pm ET\/12pm PT"},"content":{"rendered":"<p class=\"p1\"><span class=\"featured__span-first-words\">On May 21 at 3pm<\/span> ET\/12pm PT, we&#8217;re hosting an <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/04\/16\/announcing-the-extra-crunch-live-event-series\/\">Extra Crunch Live<\/a> session with Steve Case and Clara Sieg of Revolution.<\/p>\n<p class=\"p1\">This chat is the latest in our <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/04\/16\/announcing-the-extra-crunch-live-event-series\/\">growing series<\/a> featuring notable investors, entrepreneurs and technologists. Previously, TechCrunch editorial staff sat down (virtually, of course) with <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/ecl\/\">Cowboy Ventures&#8217; Aileen Lee and Ted Wang, Sequoia&#8217;s Roelof Botha and Mark Cuban, to name a few.<\/a><\/p>\n<p class=\"p1\">There\u2019s a lot to talk about with Case and Sieg, and <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/subscribe\/?tpcc=revolutionpost\">Extra Crunch members<\/a> are encouraged to come with their own set of questions to ask these renowned investors. Revolution is known for its wide range of investments, inside and out of the Valley, so we\u2019re curious how the firm is addressing the COVID-19 crisis.<\/p>\n<p class=\"p1\"><a class=\"crunchbase-link\" href=\"https:\/\/crunchbase.com\/person\/steve-case\" target=\"_blank\" data-type=\"person\" data-entity=\"steve-case\">Steve Case <span class=\"crunchbase-tooltip-indicator\"><\/span><\/a> was a co-founder of AOL and led the company as it became the internet giant of the &#8217;90s \u2014 and did so outside of Silicon Valley. Because of this, he\u2019s long been a champion of startups from other regions. Yet the firm still has a presence in Silicon Valley, and Clara Sieg has run that effort since 2012 after joining in 2010.<\/p>\n<p class=\"p1\">We\u2019re curious how Case, Sieg and other partners are advising startups to weather this storm. With investments throughout the country, <a class=\"crunchbase-link\" href=\"https:\/\/crunchbase.com\/organization\/revolution\" target=\"_blank\" data-type=\"organization\" data-entity=\"revolution\">Revolution <span class=\"crunchbase-tooltip-indicator\"><\/span><\/a> is in a unique position to have a holistic perspective on how the COVID-19 crisis is affecting startups.<\/p>\n<p class=\"p1\">Are they still funding startups right now? What metrics are they looking for? What regions of the country do they see less effected than others and which are hardest hit?<\/p>\n<p class=\"p1\">We have questions and we hope they have answers.<\/p>\n<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/subscribe\/?tpcc=revolutionpost\">Extra Crunch members<\/a> can ask their own questions directly in the Zoom Q&amp;A. So come prepared! You can find the full information for the chat below. See you there!<\/p>\n<p><div class=\"extra-crunch-offer-container\"><\/div>","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>On May 21 at 3pm ET\/12pm PT, we&#8217;re hosting an Extra Crunch Live session with Steve Case and Clara Sieg of Revolution. This chat is the latest in our growing series featuring notable investors, entrepreneurs and technologists. Crunch Live","slug":"extra-crunch-live","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576757259"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576757259"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576757259"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576757259"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576757259"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":3731,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/revolution\/","name":"revolution","slug":"revolution","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/3731"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=3731"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=3731"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=3731"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=3731"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":225567,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/steve-case\/","name":"steve case","slug":"steve-case","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/225567"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=225567"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=225567"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=225567"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=225567"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[]]}},{"id":1990027,"date":"2020-05-18T02:53:31","date_gmt":"2020-05-18T09:53:31","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=1990027"},"modified":"2020-05-18T06:24:32","modified_gmt":"2020-05-18T13:24:32","slug":"huawei-uncertainties-new-us-chip-rules-tsmc","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/05\/18\/huawei-uncertainties-new-us-chip-rules-tsmc\/","title":{"rendered":"Huawei admits uncertainty following new US chip curbs"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Following the U.S. government&#8217;s <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/05\/15\/u-s-china-trade-enters-new-era-after-overnight-huawei-foxconn-and-tsmc-announcements\/\">announcement<\/a> that would further thwart Huawei&#8217;s chip-making capability, the Chinese telecoms equipment giant condemned the new ruling for being &#8220;arbitrary and pernicious.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;Huawei categorically opposes the amendments made by the <a class=\"crunchbase-link\" href=\"https:\/\/crunchbase.com\/organization\/u-s-department-of-commerce\" target=\"_blank\" data-type=\"organization\" data-entity=\"u-s-department-of-commerce\">U.S. Department of Commerce <span class=\"crunchbase-tooltip-indicator\"><\/span><\/a> to its foreign direct product rule that target Huawei specifically,&#8221; said Huawei Monday at its annual analyst summit in Shenzhen.<\/p>\n<p>The new curbs, which <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/05\/15\/u-s-china-trade-enters-new-era-after-overnight-huawei-foxconn-and-tsmc-announcements\/\">dropped on Friday<\/a>, would ban Huawei from using U.S. software and hardware in certain strategic semiconductor processes. This will affect all foundries using U.S. technologies, including those located abroad, some of which are Huawei&#8217;s key suppliers.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>Earlier on Monday, the Nikkei Asian Review reported citing sources that <a href=\"https:\/\/www.tsmc.com\/english\/default.htm\">Taiwanese Semiconductor Manufacturing Co.<\/a>, the world\u2019s largest contract semiconductor that powers many of Huawei&#8217;s high-end phones, has stopped taking new orders from Huawei, one of its largest clients. Huawei declined to comment while TSMC said the report was <a href=\"https:\/\/www.reuters.com\/article\/us-usa-huawei-tech-tsmc\/tsmc-stops-new-huawei-orders-after-u-s-restrictions-nikkei-idUSKBN22U0EW\">\u201cpurely market rumor\u201d.<\/a><\/p>\n<p>Decisions from TSMC point to its attempt to strengthen bonds with the U.S. though, as it&#8217;s planning a new $12 billion advanced chip factory <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/05\/15\/u-s-china-trade-enters-new-era-after-overnight-huawei-foxconn-and-tsmc-announcements\/\">in Arizona<\/a>\u00a0with support from the state and the U.S. federal government.<\/p>\n<p>At the Monday conference, Huawei&#8217;s rotating chairman Guo Ping admitted that while the firm is able to design some semiconductor parts such as integrated circuits (IC), it remains &#8220;incapable of doing a lot of other things.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;Survival is the keyword for us at present,&#8221; he said.<\/p>\n<p>Huawei stated the latest U.S. ban would not only affect its own business in over 170 countries, where it has spent &#8220;hundreds of billions of dollars,&#8221; but also the wider ecosystem around the world.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;In the long run, [the U.S. ban] will damage the trust and collaboration within the global semiconductor industry which many industries depend on, increasing conflict and loss within these industries.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>Huawei has announced a raft of contingency measures ever since the Trump administration began slapping technology sanctions on it, including one that had cut it off certain <a class=\"crunchbase-link\" href=\"https:\/\/crunchbase.com\/organization\/android\" target=\"_blank\" data-type=\"organization\" data-entity=\"android\">Android <span class=\"crunchbase-tooltip-indicator\"><\/span><\/a> services from Google.<\/p>\n<p>Huawei said at the summit that it had doubled down on investment in overseas developers in an effort to lure them to its operating system. Some 1.4 million developers have joined Huawei Mobile Services or HMS, a 150% jump from 2019. For comparison, iOS in 2018 counted <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2018\/06\/04\/app-store-hits-20m-registered-developers-at-100b-in-revenues-500m-visitors-per-week\/\">20 million registered developers<\/a>, who collectively made about $100 billion in revenues. The question for Huawei is how much money app makers can generate from its ecosystem.<\/p>\n<p>In its search to identify alternatives to Google&#8217;s app suite in Europe, it has partnered up with navigation services <a href=\"https:\/\/www.reuters.com\/article\/us-tomtom-huawei-tech\/tomtom-closes-deal-with-huawei-for-use-of-maps-and-services-spokesman-idUSKBN1ZG1SW\">TomTom<\/a> and <a href=\"https:\/\/www.forbes.com\/sites\/zakdoffman\/2020\/04\/26\/huawei-surprises-millions-of-users-with-stunning-google-alternative\/#20e87fc655b0\">Here<\/a>, search engine <a href=\"https:\/\/www.huaweicentral.com\/qwant-search-huawei\/\">Qwant<\/a> and news app <a href=\"https:\/\/consumer.huawei.com\/en\/press\/news\/2020\/huawei-appgallery-with-news-uk-offer-new-services\/\">News UK.\u00a0<\/a><\/p>\n<p><audio style=\"display: none;\" controls=\"controls\"><\/audio><\/p>\n<p><audio style=\"display: none;\" controls=\"controls\"><\/audio><\/p>\n<p><audio style=\"display: none;\" controls=\"controls\"><\/audio><\/p>\n<p><audio style=\"display: none;\" controls=\"controls\"><\/audio><\/p>\n<p><audio style=\"display: none;\" controls=\"controls\"><\/audio><\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Following the U.S. government&#8217;s announcement that would further thwart Huawei&#8217;s chip-making capability, the Chinese telecoms equipment giant condemned the new ruling for being &#8220;arbitrary and pernicious.&#8221; &#8220;Huawei categorically opposes the amendments made by the U.S. Department of Commerce to its foreign direct product rule that target Huawei specifically,&#8221; said Huawei Monday at its annual analyst gets another $7 million in funding from 01 Advisors and the Slack Fund"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><a href=\"https:\/\/www.electric.ai\/\">Electric<\/a>, a platform that aims to put IT departments in the cloud, today announced new funding following a continuation of its Series B earlier this year.<\/p>\n<p>Dick Costolo and Adam Bain (<a class=\"crunchbase-link\" href=\"https:\/\/crunchbase.com\/organization\/01-advisors-01\" target=\"_blank\" data-type=\"organization\" data-entity=\"01-advisors-01\">01 Advisors) <span class=\"crunchbase-tooltip-indicator\"><\/span><\/a> and the <a class=\"crunchbase-link\" href=\"https:\/\/crunchbase.com\/organization\/slack-fund\" target=\"_blank\" data-type=\"organization\" data-entity=\"slack-fund\">Slack Fund <span class=\"crunchbase-tooltip-indicator\"><\/span><\/a> participated in the $7 million capital infusion.<\/p>\n<p>01 Advisors put up the majority of the financing ($5 million) with the Slack Fund putting up a little under $1 million and other insiders covering the rest, according to <a class=\"crunchbase-link\" href=\"https:\/\/crunchbase.com\/organization\/electric\" target=\"_blank\" data-type=\"organization\" data-entity=\"electric\">Electric <span class=\"crunchbase-tooltip-indicator\"><\/span><\/a> founder and CEO Ryan Denehy.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>The funding situation with Electric is a bit unique. Electric raised a <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2019\/01\/23\/electric-the-startup-that-automates-it-raises-25-million-from-ggv\/\">$25 million Series B round led by GGV in January of 2019<\/a>. In March of this year, just before the lockdown, the company <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/03\/10\/electric-reopens-series-b-to-make-room-for-dick-costolo-and-adam-bain\/\">reopened the Series B<\/a> at a higher valuation to make room for Dick Costolo and Adam Bain, raising an additional $14.5 million.<\/p>\n<p>Then the coronavirus pandemic rocked the globe. On Monday March 9, the <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/03\/09\/wall-streets-terrible-horrible-no-good-very-bad-day-ends-with-the-dow-down-2000\/\">stock market felt it<\/a>, triggering a temporary halt on trading. The following week was total financial chaos.<\/p>\n<p>That&#8217;s when Adam Bain called up Denehy again. They &#8216;rapped out&#8217; about the potential for Electric during this turbulent time.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;The increase in remote work is going to be dramatic,&#8221; said Denehy, relaying his conversation with Bain. &#8220;Larger companies are going to get smarter about budgeting and there is a lot of urgency for them to find ways to spend money around back office tasks like IT more efficiently. Electric becomes more appealing because, dollar for dollar, it&#8217;s a lot more efficient than building a big IT department.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>The first week of April, Bain called Denehy again, this time saying that 01 Advisors wanted to put in more money into Electric.<\/p>\n<p>Electric is a platform designed to support the existing IT department of an organization, or in some cases, replace an outsourced IT department. Most of IT&#8217;s responsibilities focus on administration, distribution and maintenance of software programs. Electric allows IT to install its software on every corporate machine, giving the department a bird&#8217;s-eye view of the organization&#8217;s IT situation. It also aims to give IT departments more time to focus on real problem-solving and troubleshooting tasks.<\/p>\n<p>From their own machine, lead IT professionals can grant and revoke permissions, assign roles and ensure all employees&#8217; software is up to date.<\/p>\n<p>Electric is also integrated with the APIs of top software programs, like Dropbox and G-suite, letting IT handle most of their day-to-day tasks through the Electric dashboard. Moreover, Electric is also integrated with Slack, letting folks within the organization flag an issue or ask a question from the platform where they spend the most time.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;The biggest challenge for Electric is keeping up with demand,&#8221; said Jason Spinell from the Slack Fund, who also mentioned that he passed on investing in Electric&#8217;s seed round and is &#8220;excited to sort of rectify [his] mistake.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>Electric also added a new self-service product that can live in the dock, letting employees look at all the software applications provided by the organization from their remote office.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;There are so many stretched IT departments now that have to do a lot more with a lot less,&#8221; said Denehy. &#8220;There are also companies who were working with an outsourced IT provider and relied on them showing up to the office a few times a week, and all of a sudden that doesn&#8217;t work anymore.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>With the current ecosystem, Electric is continuing to spend on marketing but with 180 percent increase in interest from potential clients in the pipeline, according to Denehy.<\/p>\n<p><em>Editor&#8217;s Note: This article has been updated to reflect the accurate amount invested by participants in the round.<\/em><\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Electric, a platform that aims to put IT departments in the cloud, today announced new funding following a continuation of its Series B earlier this year. Dick Costolo and Adam Bain (01 Advisors) and the Slack Fund participated in the $7 million capital infusion. 01 Advisors put up the majority of the financing ($5 million) fund","slug":"slack-fund","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/449551094"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=449551094"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=449551094"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=449551094"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=449551094"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[{"id":576768306,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?taxonomy=_tc_cb_tag_taxonomy&term=ryan-denehy-person","name":"ryan-denehy-person","slug":"ryan-denehy-person","taxonomy":"_tc_cb_tag_taxonomy","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/crunchbase_tag\/576768306"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/crunchbase_tag"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/_tc_cb_tag_taxonomy"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?crunchbase_tag=576768306"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[]]}}],"ec":[{"id":1989555,"date":"2020-05-17T08:00:41","date_gmt":"2020-05-17T15:00:41","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=1989555"},"modified":"2020-05-15T15:53:06","modified_gmt":"2020-05-15T22:53:06","slug":"the-great-reset","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/05\/17\/the-great-reset\/","title":{"rendered":"The Great Reset"},"content":{"rendered":"<div class=\"article__contributor-byline-wrapper\">\n<div class=\"article__contributor-byline\">\n\t<div class=\"contributor-byline__contributor\">\n\t\t<div class=\"byline__author\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<span class=\"byline__author-name\">Ann Miura-Ko<\/span>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<span class=\"byline__author-title\" style=\"display: block;\">Contributor<\/span>\n\t\t<\/div>\n\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"contributor__twitter\">\n\t\t\t<a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/annimaniac\">\n\t\t\t\t\t<svg class=\"icon icon--twitter icon--white\" viewBox=\"0 0 20 20\" version=\"1.1\" aria-labelledby=\"title\">\n\t\t<title>Share on Twitter<\/title>\n\t\t<path d=\"M20,4c-0.7,0.3-1.5,0.6-2.4,0.7c0.9-0.5,1.5-1.4,1.8-2.3c-0.8,0.5-1.7,0.8-2.6,1C16.1,2.5,15,2,13.8,2c-2.3,0-4.1,1.9-4.1,4.2c0,0.3,0,0.7,0.1,1C6.4,7,3.4,5.4,1.4,2.9C1,3.5,0.8,4.1,0.8,4.9c0,1.4,0.7,2.7,1.8,3.5C2,8.4,1.4,8.2,0.8,7.9v0.1c0,2,1.4,3.7,3.3,4.1c-0.4,0.1-0.7,0.2-1.1,0.2c-0.3,0-0.5,0-0.8-0.1c0.5,1.7,2,2.9,3.8,2.9c-1.4,1.1-3.2,2-5.1,2c-0.3,0-0.7,0-1-0.1c1.8,1.2,4,1.7,6.3,1.7c7.5,0,11.7-6.4,11.7-12V6.1C18.8,5.6,19.4,4.8,20,4z\"\/>\t<\/svg>\n\t\t\t\t<\/a>\n\t\t<\/div>\n\t\t\t<\/div>\n\n\t\t<div class=\"contributor-byline__bio\">\n\t\tAnn Miura-Ko is a co-founding partner at <a href=\"https:\/\/floodgate.com\/\">Floodgate<\/a>, a seed-stage VC firm. A repeat member of the Forbes Midas List and the New York Times Top 20 Venture Capitalists Worldwide, she earned a PhD in math modeling of cybersecurity at Stanford University.\t<\/div>\n\t\n\t\t<div class=\"contributor-byline__more-articles\">\n\t\t<span class=\"more-articles-title\">More posts by this contributor<\/span>\n\t\t<ul class=\"more-articles-list\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/01\/31\/you-need-a-minimum-viable-company-not-a-minimum-viable-product-2\/\">True product-market fit is a minimum viable company<\/a><\/li>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/01\/31\/you-need-a-minimum-viable-company-not-a-minimum-viable-product\/\">You need a minimum viable company, not a minimum viable product<\/a><\/li>\n\t\t\t\t\t<\/ul>\n\t<\/div>\n\t<\/div>\n<\/div><p id=\"speakable-summary\"><span class=\"featured__span-first-words\">Talk of an economic<\/span> downturn can be frightening, especially one precipitated by a pervasive health crisis. At times, I\u2019m overwhelmed by the images of countless patients on life-support and the near-endless streams of statistics regurgitating bad news.<\/p>\n<p>Having started in venture at the beginning of two recessions, I\u2019ve seen how the startup industry functions during economic trouble. My second day of work at Charles River Ventures was September 11th, 2001. My first project, analyzing the VC industry, propelled the firm to return more than 60% of its fund to investors, going from a $1.2 billion fund to $450 million. In May 2008, Mike Maples and I founded Floodgate in the midst of the Great Recession. We learned that great founders won\u2019t wait for a better economic moment to start a company.<\/p>\n<p>While we are currently embroiled in personal and professional circumstances unimaginable even three months ago, these very challenges will form the basis of incredibly innovative ideas. In order for the world to move forward, we need our greatest minds to imagine a brighter future and create solutions to make it a reality.<\/p>\n<p>When I analyze our society and novel health situation, one thing is certain: COVID-19 is a paradigm-shifting event, creating massively accelerated social and economic change.<\/p>\n<h2>The Great Reset is not just another economic event<\/h2>\n<p>Our current situation is unique. It\u2019s not merely a cyclical economic event, nor is it a standalone health crisis. What we are experiencing is not just an inflection point: it\u2019s a societal phase-change unlike anything we have ever seen. We face an epic choice of how we move forward, and the decisions we make today will shape an entire generation.<\/p>\n<p>Here\u2019s why: COVID-19 is prompting us to reset many of our most fundamental behaviors. These changes are impacting our financial system, with effects visible throughout our homes, businesses and even the concept of \u201cworkplace\u201d itself.<\/p>\n<h2>COVID-19 is pervasive<\/h2>\n<p>As a global pandemic, the virus itself has spread to nearly every country in the world.<\/p>\n<p>Between February 20 and March 26, 100% of the world\u2019s 20 largest economies implemented government-mandated social distancing. Globally, the number of scheduled airline flights is down 64%. In some countries, like Spain and Germany, flight numbers are down by more than 90%.<\/p>\n<p>Since the timeline for lifting government restrictions is unclear \u2014 and even then, scientists are uncertain how the virus will spread \u2014 the question lingers: How long will this go on?<\/p>\n<p>COVID-19\u2019s impact is uncertain, long-term and potentially undulating, affecting every facet of our lives. You can\u2019t simply wait it out with the expectation that industries will rebound. In 2001, September 11 felt pervasive, but its economic impact ultimately stemmed from just one single incident and the resulting fear&#8230; and that one single incident still cost more than three trillion dollars. How much larger will COVID-19 be?<div class=\"extra-crunch-offer-container\"><\/div>","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>We\u2019re entering a new paradigm, and that brings possibilities. Now, founders, is the time to Twice a month, we ask them to share their most effective growth tactics, and we compile them into this Growth Report.<\/p>\n<p>This is how you stay up-to-date on growth marketing tactics \u2014 with advice that\u2019s hard to find elsewhere.<\/p>\n<p>Our community consists of startup founders and heads of growth. You can participate by joining Demand Curve\u2019s <a href=\"https:\/\/www.demandcurve.com\/?utm_source=tc&amp;utm_campaign=tc&amp;utm_medium=tc\">marketing training program<\/a> or its <a href=\"https:\/\/www.demandcurve.com\/slack\">Slack group<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p>Without further ado, onto our community\u2019s advice.<\/p>\n<hr \/>\n<h2>Use an omnichannel approach for more remote sales<\/h2>\n<p><em>Insights from Paige Harris of <a href=\"http:\/\/smile.io\/\">Smile.io<\/a>.<\/em><\/p>\n<p>High-margin consumer goods justify a personalized sales funnel. That\u2019s why companies like offline cosmetics retailers employ a small army of sales reps to make calls and do home demos.<\/p>\n<p>In today\u2019s COVID-19 world, retailers are having to move this process from in-person to online. It\u2019s easier said than done.<\/p>\n<p>Here\u2019s one process that some offline retailers (with high-margin products) are finding works:<\/p>\n<ol>\n<li>Turn those sales calls into Zoom sessions: Sales reps adapt their home demos to Zoom demos.<div class=\"extra-crunch-offer-container\"><\/div>","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>B2B leads typically require multiple touches before they become customers. You can help leads move quicker through your funnel by dynamically adjusting the landing page content they marketing","slug":"referral-marketing","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/996694"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=996694"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=996694"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=996694"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=996694"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[]]}},{"id":1985849,"date":"2020-05-14T06:00:13","date_gmt":"2020-05-14T13:00:13","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=1985849"},"modified":"2020-05-14T16:54:44","modified_gmt":"2020-05-14T23:54:44","slug":"7-top-mobility-vcs-discuss-covid-19-strategies-and-trends","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/05\/14\/7-top-mobility-vcs-discuss-covid-19-strategies-and-trends\/","title":{"rendered":"7 top mobility VCs discuss COVID-19 strategies and trends"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><span class=\"featured__span-first-words\">As COVID-19 swept<\/span> across the globe, no sector lay untouched, but perhaps no industry was more disrupted than transportation.<\/p>\n<p>Airlines slashed routes, public transit use plummeted, ridership on <a class=\"crunchbase-link\" href=\"https:\/\/crunchbase.com\/organization\/uber\" target=\"_blank\" data-type=\"organization\" data-entity=\"uber\">Uber, <span class=\"crunchbase-tooltip-indicator\"><\/span><\/a> Lyft and other ride-hailing platforms dropped and shared scooter companies pulled products from city streets. Meanwhile, e-bike sales bloomed and on-demand delivery, including services using autonomous robots, exploded.<\/p>\n<p>Transportation companies have been forced to adapt \u2014 quickly \u2014 to this new reality. Uber, for example, found itself in a position where it felt both right to <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/05\/06\/uber-is-laying-off-3700-as-rides-plummet-due-to-covid-19\/\">lay off thousands of employees <\/a>as it planned to <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/05\/06\/uber-is-laying-off-3700-as-rides-plummet-due-to-covid-19\/\">inject $170 million into micromobility startup Lime<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p>The upshot: Along with the pain, crises can also be a catalyst for innovation. TechCrunch spoke to seven venture capitalists about how COVID-19 affected their portfolio and investment strategy, and asked their advice for startup founders as well as where they think the next and overlooked hot opportunity will be:<\/p>\n<ul>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/www.alsop-louie.com\/team\/ernestine-fu\/\">Ernestine Fu<\/a>, Alsop Louie Partners<\/li>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/urban.us\/about-us\/stonly-baptiste\/\">Stonly Baptiste<\/a> &amp; <a href=\"https:\/\/urban.us\/about-us\/shaun-abrahamson\/\">Shaun Abrahamson<\/a>, Urban.us<\/li>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/shastaventures.com\/team\/rob-coneybeer\/\">Rob Coneybeer<\/a>, Shasta Ventures<\/li>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/luxcapital.com\/team\/shahin-farshchi\/\">Shahin Farshchi<\/a>, Lux Capital<\/li>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/in\/k8schox\">Kate Schox<\/a>, Trucks VC<\/li>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/www.autotechvc.com\/team\">Jeff Peters<\/a>, Autotech Ventures<\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<h2>Ernestine Fu, Alsop Louie Partners<\/h2>\n<p><strong>How has COVID-19 impacted your investment strategy?\u00a0<\/strong><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Early-stage venture capital is about investing in the steady growth and potential of a business over time. We\u2019re in it for the long term, and the economy will eventually rebound. We\u2019re preserving dry powder for existing investments, but at the same time, I\u2019m reminded that some of the best venture-backed businesses were founded and funded during recessionary times (e.g. Google, Salesforce, Instagram). So we\u2019re keeping our eyes open for promising young startups too.<\/span><\/p>\n<p><b>What is your advice to startups in your portfolio right now?<\/b><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">COVID-19 is an existential event in all of our lives and businesses. Stay positive and be empathetic \u2014 protect your employees and communicate often, maintain the financial health of your business and know you need to adapt to the change that will continue to happen. <div class=\"extra-crunch-offer-container\"><\/div>","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>As COVID-19 swept across the globe, no sector lay untouched, but perhaps no industry was more disrupted than transportation. Airlines slashed routes, public transit use plummeted, ridership on Uber, Lyft and other ride-hailing platforms dropped and shared scooter companies pulled products from city streets. Meanwhile, e-bike sales bloomed and on-demand delivery, including services using autonomous views on the future of work, coffee shops and neighborhoods in a post-pandemic world"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><span class=\"featured__span-first-words\">The novel coronavirus<\/span> pandemic has disordered traditional notions of work, travel, socializing and the way we collaborate with colleagues.<\/p>\n<p>It seems obvious that the future of work must evolve, given what we&#8217;re experiencing, but what will that future look like? Which changes are here to stay and which ones will revert the moment offices reopen?<\/p>\n<p><a class=\"crunchbase-link\" href=\"https:\/\/crunchbase.com\/organization\/techcrunch\" target=\"_blank\" data-type=\"organization\" data-entity=\"techcrunch\">TechCrunch <span class=\"crunchbase-tooltip-indicator\"><\/span><\/a> has been a WFH employer for essentially its entire existence. Our staff is distributed across major startup hubs like SF and NYC, but we also have writers in smaller cities around the world, so we compiled reflections and thoughts from three of them about how remote work has changed our lifestyles and what we predict to see in the next few years, post-COVID 19.<\/p>\n<p><a class=\"crunchbase-link\" href=\"https:\/\/crunchbase.com\/person\/devin-coldewey\" target=\"_blank\" data-type=\"person\" data-entity=\"devin-coldewey\">Devin Coldewey <span class=\"crunchbase-tooltip-indicator\"><\/span><\/a> talks about what\u2019s going to change with coffee shops and co-working spaces, Alex Wilhelm discusses the future of the home office setup and Danny Crichton talks about the revitalization of urban and semi-urban neighborhoods.<\/p>\n<h2>Devin Coldewey on coffee shops and more flexible work arrangements<\/h2>\n<p>I&#8217;ve worked from home for over a decade and part of what makes it so lovely is the ability to do my work from a nearby cafe, or even a restaurant or bar. I&#8217;m lucky in that my part of the city is famously packed with excellent coffee shops, but in the time I&#8217;ve lived here I&#8217;ve seen them grow increasingly packed with \u2014 well, people like me. Some days they seem more like co-working spaces than cafes \u2014 and this is something business owners and neighborhoods are going to need to acknowledge one way or the other.<\/p>\n<p>Most urban and suburban American communities were formed around the convention of commuting, which means fewer work-related resources where people live. Instead, we have all the restaurants, bodegas, thrift stores and all the other things that cater to people who aren&#8217;t working.<div "This Week in Apps: Houseparty battles Messenger, Telegram drops crypto plans, Instagram Lite is gone"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><span class=\"featured__span-first-words\">Welcome back to This\u00a0Week<\/span> in Apps, the Extra Crunch series that recaps the latest OS news, the applications they support and the money that flows through it all.<\/p>\n<p id=\"speakable-summary\">The app industry is as hot as ever, with\u00a0<a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/01\/15\/app-stores-saw-record-204-billion-app-downloads-in-2019-consumer-spend-of-120-billion\/\">a record<\/a>\u00a0204 billion downloads and $120 billion in consumer spending in 2019. People are now\u00a0<a href=\"https:\/\/www.emarketer.com\/content\/average-us-time-spent-with-mobile-in-2019-has-increased\">spending<\/a>\u00a03 hours and 40 minutes per day using apps, rivaling TV. Apps aren\u2019t just a way to pass idle hours \u2014 they\u2019re a big business. In 2019, mobile-first companies had a\u00a0<a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/01\/15\/app-stores-saw-record-204-billion-app-downloads-in-2019-consumer-spend-of-120-billion\/\">combined<\/a>\u00a0$544 billion valuation, 6.5x higher than those without a mobile focus.<\/p>\n<p>In this Extra Crunch series, we help you keep up with the latest news from the world of apps, delivered on a weekly basis.<\/p>\n<p>This week we\u2019re continuing to look at how the coronavirus outbreak is impacting the world of mobile applications, including the latest news about COVID-19 apps, Facebook and Houseparty&#8217;s battle to dominate the online hangout, the game that everyone&#8217;s playing during quarantine, and more. We also look at the new allegations against TikTok, the demise of a popular &#8220;Lite&#8221; app, new apps offering parental controls, Telegram killing its crypto plans and many other stories, including a hefty load of funding and M&amp;A.<\/p>\n<h1><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\">Headlines<\/span><\/h1>\n<h2><strong>Contact tracing and COVID-19 apps in the news\u00a0<\/strong><\/h2>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Global<\/strong>: WHO readies its coronavirus app for symptom-checking and possibly contact tracing. A<a href=\"https:\/\/www.reuters.com\/article\/health-coronavirus-who-apps\/who-readies-coronavirus-app-for-checking-symptoms-possibly-contact-tracing-idUSKBN22L06L\"> WHO official told Reuters on Friday<\/a> the new app will ask people about their symptoms and offer guidance on whether they may have COVID-19. Information on testing will be personalized to the user&#8217;s country. The organization is considering adding a Bluetooth-based, contact-tracing feature, too. A version of the app will launch globally, but individual countries will be able to use the underlying technology and add features to release their own versions. Engineers from Google and Microsoft have volunteered their time over the past few weeks to develop the app, which is available open-source on GitHub.<\/li>\n<li><strong>U.S.<\/strong>: Apple&#8217;s <a href=\"https:\/\/apps.apple.com\/us\/app\/apple-covid-19\/id1504132184\">COVID-19 app,<\/a> developed in partnership with the CDC, FEMA and the White House, received its first major update since its March debut. The new version includes recommendations for healthcare workers to align with CDC guidelines, best practices for quarantining if you&#8217;ve been exposed to COVID-19 and new information for pregnancy and newborns.<\/li>\n<li><strong>India<\/strong>: New Delhi\u2019s contact-tracing app, Aarogya Setu, <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/05\/12\/aarogya-setu-india-contact-tracing-app-10-crore\/\">has reached 100 million users<\/a> out of India\u2019s total 450 million smartphone owners in 41 days after its release, despite privacy concerns. The app helps users self-assess if they caught COVID-19 by answering a series of questions and will alert them if they came into contact with someone who&#8217;s infected. The app has come under fire for how it stores user location data and logs the details for those reporting symptoms. The app is required to use Indian railways, which has boosted adoption.<\/li>\n<li><strong>Iceland<\/strong>: Iceland has one of the most-downloaded contact-tracing apps, with 38% of its population using it. But despite this, <a href=\"https:\/\/www.businessinsider.com\/iceland-contact-tracing-not-gamechanger-2020-5\">the country said it has not been a &#8220;game-changer<\/a>&#8221; in terms of tracking the virus and only worked well when coupled with manual contact tracing \u2014 meaning phone calls that asked who someone had been in contact with. In addition, the low download rate indicates it may be difficult to get people to use these apps when they launch in larger markets.<\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<h2><strong>Consumer advocacy groups say TikTok is still violating COPPA<div class=\"extra-crunch-offer-container\"><\/div>","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>We continue to look at how the coronavirus outbreak is impacting the world of Etrade go down as stocks soar"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Stock trading platforms Robinhood and Etrade are down on a day that&#8217;s seen rare gains in the U.S. stock market.<\/p>\n<p>Neither company acknowledged immediate outages with their platforms. Robinhood&#8217;s <a href=\"https:\/\/status.robinhood.com\/\">status page<\/a> says all systems are &#8220;operational,&#8221; but its website crashed on loading, stating: &#8220;An internal error occured! [sic].&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>After weeks of turbulent markets largely driven by coronavirus concerns, the Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJIA) is up 3% in early morning trading.<\/p>\n<p>Users quickly turned to <a class=\"crunchbase-link\" href=\"https:\/\/crunchbase.com\/organization\/twitter\" target=\"_blank\" data-type=\"organization\" data-entity=\"twitter\">Twitter <span class=\"crunchbase-tooltip-indicator\"><\/span><\/a> to complain.<\/p>\n<p>Robinhood, which earlier this month raised $280 million <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/05\/04\/robinhood-raises-280m-pushing-its-valuation-to-8-3b\/\">pushing its valuation to $8.3 billion<\/a>, took heat in March after two days of outages saw users unable to trade on the platform. The financial startup said it would offer case-by-case compensation to its 10 million users for their troubles. Months earlier, the company <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2019\/11\/05\/robinhood-has-a-glitch-thats-letting-users-borrow-far-more-than-they-should\/\">admitted a glitch<\/a> that let users borrow more money than they were allowed.<\/p>\n<p><a class=\"crunchbase-link\" href=\"https:\/\/crunchbase.com\/organization\/morgan-stanley\" target=\"_blank\" data-type=\"organization\" data-entity=\"morgan-stanley\">Morgan Stanley <span class=\"crunchbase-tooltip-indicator\"><\/span><\/a> bought Etrade <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/02\/20\/robinhood-profiles-morgan-stanley-etrade\/\">earlier this year<\/a> for $13 billion.<\/p>\n<p>We&#8217;ll have more as we know it.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"ny2OlCOY3y\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/03\/03\/robinhood-will-offer-case-by-case-compensation-for-its-outage-on-the-day-markets-gained-1-1-trillion\/\">Down again, Robinhood will offer &#8216;case-by-case&#8217; compensation for its outage on the day markets gained $1.1 trillion<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe title=\"&#8220;Down again, Robinhood will offer &#8216;case-by-case&#8217; compensation for its outage on the day markets gained $1.1 trillion&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/03\/03\/robinhood-will-offer-case-by-case-compensation-for-its-outage-on-the-day-markets-gained-1-1-trillion\/embed\/#?secret=ny2OlCOY3y\" data-secret=\"ny2OlCOY3y\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Stock trading platforms Robinhood and Etrade are down on a day that&#8217;s seen rare gains in the U.S. stock market. ags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=4269"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=4269"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=4269"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=4269"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":1417,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/money\/","name":"money","slug":"money","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/1417"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=1417"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=1417"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=1417"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=1417"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":433306,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/morgan-stanley\/","name":"morgan efield-companies?tags=52860"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=52860"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=52860"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":599182,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/twitter\/","name":"Twitter","slug":"twitter","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/599182"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=599182"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=599182"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=599182"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=599182"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[]]}},{"id":1989927,"date":"2020-05-18T07:05:43","date_gmt":"2020-05-18T14:05:43","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=1989927"},"modified":"2020-05-18T07:17:49","modified_gmt":"2020-05-18T14:17:49","slug":"u-s-house-approves-remote-voting-though-the-tech-is-unclear","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/05\/18\/u-s-house-approves-remote-voting-though-the-tech-is-unclear\/","title":{"rendered":"U.S. House approves remote voting, though the tech is unclear"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Congress will allow remote voting for the first time in its history, after the U.S. House approved Resolution 965 late Friday in response to the coronavirus pandemic.<\/p>\n<p>The measure \u2014 sponsored by Massachusetts Representative <a href=\"https:\/\/rules.house.gov\/about\/chairman-mcgovern\">Jim McGovern<\/a> \u2014 authorizes proxy voting by members for renewable periods of 45 days and allows for remote participation in committee hearings.<\/p>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/www.govtrack.us\/congress\/bills\/116\/hres965\/text\">H.R. 965<\/a> could also permanently alter the way Congress operates through a provision that establishes a bi-partisan process to explore digital voting away from Capitol Hill.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>Per the directive, &#8220;The chair of the Committee on House Administration, in consultation with the ranking minority member, shall study the feasibility of using technology to conduct remote voting in the House, and shall provide certification&#8230;that operable and secure technology exists.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>Previous House rules required in person voting only. The\u00a0<a href=\"https:\/\/www.senate.gov\/general\/Features\/votes.htm\">Senate still makes decisions by recording<\/a>\u00a0verbal \u201cYeas\u201d and \u201cNays\u201d on a tally sheet.<\/p>\n<p>Friday&#8217;s congressional action is another example of how COVID-19 is forcing every organization in the U.S. to overhaul longstanding ways of doing things, usually through a mix of digital tools.<\/p>\n<p>We still don&#8217;t have clear details on what tech the U.S. House will use to implement both the short and longer term provisions of H.R. 965.<\/p>\n<p>The proxy voting arrangement will allow members to vote remotely through designated representatives on Capitol Hill \u2014 effectively a form of pinch-hitting for Congress. For remote participation in hearings, there are a range of options that could be selected \u2014 from <a class=\"crunchbase-link\" href=\"https:\/\/crunchbase.com\/organization\/google\" target=\"_blank\" data-type=\"organization\" data-entity=\"google\">Google <span class=\"crunchbase-tooltip-indicator\"><\/span><\/a> Meet to <a class=\"crunchbase-link\" href=\"https:\/\/crunchbase.com\/organization\/microsoft\" target=\"_blank\" data-type=\"organization\" data-entity=\"microsoft\">Microsoft <span class=\"crunchbase-tooltip-indicator\"><\/span><\/a> Teams. Last week, Dr. Anthony Fauci <a href=\"https:\/\/www.yahoo.com\/entertainment\/dr-anthony-fauci-testifies-senate-223259206.html\">testified before the U.S. Senate<\/a> using Zoom.<\/p>\n<p>On determining long-term means for remote voting, that&#8217;s now up to the Chairperson of the Committee on House Administration \u2014\u00a0 representative <a href=\"https:\/\/cha.house.gov\/about\/chairperson-zoe-lofgren\">Zoe Lofgren<\/a> (D-CA) \u2014\u00a0 and the ranking minority member <a href=\"https:\/\/rodneydavis.house.gov\/\">Rodney Davis<\/a> (R-IL), who voted against H.R. 965.<\/p>\n<p>Lofgren offered a preview of how it could shape up in a <a href=\"https:\/\/cha.house.gov\/media\/press-releases\/lofgren-statement-support\">statement supporting H.R. 965<\/a> late Friday: &#8220;For voting on the floor, we will rely on a secure email system, coupled with member-driven, remotely-directed authorizations.\u00a0 This system would use secure email for proxy votes: a solid, well known, resilient technology with very low bandwidth requirements that we understand very well from a cybersecurity standpoint.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>Of course, she and Republican Congressman Davis will have to find agreement on this during a time when both parties rarely agree on anything. The <a href=\"http:\/\/clerk.house.gov\/evs\/2020\/roll107.xml\">vote on H.R. 965<\/a> was split along party lines, with 217 Dems voting in favor and not a single Republican member supporting the measure.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"lytKVhaPOc\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/03\/18\/why-congress-isnt-working-remotely-due-to-covid-19\/\">Why Congress isn&#8217;t working remotely due to COVID-19<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe title=\"&#8220;Why Congress isn&#8217;t working remotely due to COVID-19&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/03\/18\/why-congress-isnt-working-remotely-due-to-covid-19\/embed\/#?secret=lytKVhaPOc\" data-secret=\"lytKVhaPOc\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p>In the past, Congress has resisted calls to allow for remote voting. There was discussion of the need for such provisions after the September 11 attacks and <a href=\"https:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/2001_anthrax_attacks\">2001 Anthrax attacks. <\/a>These was overridden by a long time expectation that those elected to represent constituencies be physically present to vote.<\/p>\n<p>Over the last two months, it appeared the House might become a last holdout in the U.S. for in person only workplaces, as much of the country has shifted to tech-enabled measures for remote operations.<\/p>\n<p>Shortly after the coronavirus outbreak hit the U.S. in March, Congressman <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/RepSwalwell?ref_src=twsrc%5Egoogle%7Ctwcamp%5Eserp%7Ctwgr%5Eauthor\">Eric Swalwell <\/a>(D-CA) pressed <a href=\"https:\/\/swalwell.house.gov\/media-center\/press-releases\/swalwell-crawford-reintroduce-mobile-resolution\">a resolution<\/a>\u00a0with Arkansas Representative Rick Crawford (R-AR) that would allow members to participate virtually in hearings and vote remotely, under special circumstances.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_1959034\" style=\"width: 2116px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-1959034\" class=\"breakout wp-image-1959034 size-full\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/03\/GettyImages-929185540.jpeg\" alt=\"US capitol building at night\" width=\"2106\" height=\"1424\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/03\/GettyImages-929185540.jpeg 2106w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/03\/GettyImages-929185540.jpeg?resize=150,101 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/03\/GettyImages-929185540.jpeg?resize=300,203 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/03\/GettyImages-929185540.jpeg?resize=768,519 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/03\/GettyImages-929185540.jpeg?resize=680,460 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/03\/GettyImages-929185540.jpeg?resize=1536,1039 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/03\/GettyImages-929185540.jpeg?resize=2048,1385 2048w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/03\/GettyImages-929185540.jpeg?resize=50,34 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 2106px) 100vw, 2106px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-1959034\" class=\"wp-caption-text\">Image Credits: Bill Dickinson\/Getty Images<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>That was nixed by House Speaker\u00a0<a class=\"crunchbase-link\" href=\"https:\/\/crunchbase.com\/person\/nancy-pelosi\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\" data-type=\"person\" data-entity=\"nancy-pelosi\">Nancy Pelosi\u00a0<\/a> who, at the time, wanted Congress to remain in session and present to pass the first coronavirus stimulus bill.<\/p>\n<p>Two months and nearly one hundred thousand American deaths later, it appears COVID-19 could force one of the more significant procedural changes in the House&#8217;s 231 year history.<\/p>\n<p>In person voting could soon be replaced with some form of two-factor authentication, digital voting. This could change longstanding patterns for how lawmakers travel, interact with constituencies, and divide their time between the Beltway and districts back home.<\/p>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/pages\/covid-19-updates\/\"><img src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/03\/covid-19-footer.png\" \/><\/a><\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Congress will allow remote voting for the first time in its history, after the U.S. House approved Resolution 965 late Friday in response to the coronavirus pandemic. The measure \u2014 sponsored by Massachusetts Representative Jim McGovern \u2014 authorizes proxy voting by members for renewable periods of 45 days and allows for remote participation in committee able":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags?post=1989927"},{"taxonomy":"_tc_cb_tag_taxonomy","embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/crunchbase_tag?post=1989927"},{"taxonomy":"tc_stories_tax","embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_stories_tax?post=1989927"},{"taxonomy":"tc_event","embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_event?post=1989927"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]},"_embedded":{"authors":[{"id":1186971,"name":"Jake Bright","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/author\/jake-bright\/","description":"<a href=\"http:\/\/www.http:\/\/jakebright.com\">Jake Bright<\/a> is a writer and author in New York City.
