Group","slug":"softbank-group","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/449560034"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=449560034"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=449560034"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=449560034"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=449560034"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":576596457,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/vision-fund\/","name":"Vision Fund","slug":"vision-fund","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576596457"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576596457"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576596457"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576596457"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576596457"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[]]}},{"id":1989979,"date":"2020-05-17T22:10:08","date_gmt":"2020-05-18T05:10:08","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=1989979"},"modified":"2020-05-18T00:02:03","modified_gmt":"2020-05-18T07:02:03","slug":"chinas-oppo-partners-with-vodafone-for-bigger-european-push","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/05\/17\/chinas-oppo-partners-with-vodafone-for-bigger-european-push\/","title":{"rendered":"China&#8217;s Oppo partners with Vodafone for bigger European push"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Huawei is facing an uphill challenge in the overseas market as its upcoming devices lack the full set of Google apps and services. That leaves ample room for its Chinese rivals to chase after foreign consumers.<\/p>\n<p>That includes <a class=\"crunchbase-link\" href=\"https:\/\/crunchbase.com\/organization\/oppo\" target=\"_blank\" data-type=\"organization\" data-entity=\"oppo\">Oppo, <span class=\"crunchbase-tooltip-indicator\"><\/span><\/a> the sister brand of Vivo under Dongguan-based electronics holding company BBK.&nbsp;In an announcement on Monday, the Chinese firm announced a partnership with Vodafone to bring its smartphones to the mobile carrier&#8217;s European markets. The deal kicks off in May and will sell Oppo&#8217;s portfolio of advanced 5G handsets as well as value-for-money models into the U.K, Germany, the Netherlands, Spain, Portugal, Romania and Turkey.<\/p>\n<p>While <a class=\"crunchbase-link\" href=\"https:\/\/crunchbase.com\/organization\/vodafone\" target=\"_blank\" data-type=\"organization\" data-entity=\"vodafone\">Vodafone <span class=\"crunchbase-tooltip-indicator\"><\/span><\/a> pulled Huawei phones from its U.K. 5G network last year following the U.S. export ban that stripped Huawei models of certain Android services, the British operator can now tap Oppo&#8217;s wide range of mobile products in a heated race to sign up 5G customers. The partners will jointly explore online sales channels as many parts of Europe&#8217;s physical premises remain closed due to the COVID-19.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>Oppo, currently the <a href=\"https:\/\/www.canalys.com\/newsroom\/canalys-china-smartphone-shipments-Q1-2020\">second-largest<\/a> smartphone vendor in its home country after Huawei, has seen a spike in sales across Europe since entering the market in mid-2018. The company was <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2019\/04\/10\/oppos-new-flagship-has-a-bit-of-everything\/\">one of the first<\/a> to launch commercially available 5G phones in Europe last year and now ranks fifth on the continent with a 2% share, according to a survey from research firm Canalys.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;Oppo has a product range that can hit many of the same segments as Huawei, enabling it to gain market share at the expense of Huawei,&#8221; Peter Richardson, research director at Counterpoint Research, explained to TechCrunch. &#8220;Oppo has always used quite a European flavour in its product design. This extends to things like colour choice, packaging, and advertising materials. This makes it acceptable to European consumers.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>Interestingly, Richardson pointed out that Oppo, which has a less &#8220;Chinese sounding&#8221; name than its domestic rivals Xiaomi and Huawei, will help it circumvent some of the &#8220;negative media surrounding China just now \u2013 first Huawei\u2019s difficulties around security threats and more recently the COVID-19 pandemic.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p><em>The article was updated on May 18, 2020 to reflect an updated statement from Oppo that Italy is not on the list of markets it targets under the Vodafone distribution partnership.<\/em><\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Huawei is facing an uphill challenge in the overseas market as its upcoming devices lack the full set of Google apps and services. That leaves ample room for its Chinese rivals to chase after foreign consumers. That includes Oppo, the sister brand of Vivo under Dongguan-based electronics holding company BBK.&nbsp;In an announcement on Monday, the 79&action=edit"}],"author":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/tc\/v1\/users\/133574232"}],"wp:featuredmedia":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/media\/1989982"}],"wp:attachment":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/media?parent=1989979"}],"wp:term":[{"taxonomy":"category","embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories?post=1989979"},{"taxonomy":"post_tag","embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags?post=1989979"},{"taxonomy":"_tc_cb_tag_taxonomy","embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/crunchbase_tag?post=1989979"},{"taxonomy":"tc_stories_tax","embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_stories_tax?post=1989979"},{"taxonomy":"tc_event","embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_event?post=1989979"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]},"_embedded":{"authors":[{"id":133574232,"name":"Rita At one point, she worked for an environmental filmmaker in Maine and a mindfulness retreat center in the Berkshires, U.S.\r\n\r\nShe studied political science and arts at Bowdoin College and is now back in her native Shenzhen, the Silicon Valley of Hardware.\r\n\r\nEmail: ritaliao@pm.me\r\n\r\nDisclosures: None","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/author\/rita-liao\/","slug":"rita-liao","avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\/\/secure.gravatar.com\/avatar\/dbaceff42174099558927b70d12e4565?s=24&d=identicon&r=g","48":"https:\/\/secure.gravatar.com\/avatar\/dbaceff42174099558927b70d12e4565?s=48&d=identicon&r=g","96":"https:\/\/secure.gravatar.com\/avatar\/dbaceff42174099558927b70d12e4565?s=96&d=identicon&r=g"},"links":{"twitter":"https:\/\/twitter.com\/ritacyliao"},"position":"","cbDescription":"","cbAvatar":"","twitter":"ritacyliao","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/tc\/v1\/users\/133574232"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/tc\/v1\/users"}]}}],"wp:featuredmedia":[{"id":1989982,"date":"2020-05-17T22:01:46","slug":"head-image-backup-1","type":"attachment","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/05\/17\/chinas-oppo-partners-with-vodafone-for-bigger-european-push\/head-image-backup-1\/","title":{"rendered":"head 1"},"guest-author-96":{"file":"head-image-backup-1-e1589778351568.jpg?resize=96,96","width":96,"height":96,"mime_type":"image\/jpeg","source_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/head-image-backup-1-e1589778351568.jpg?w=96&h=96&crop=1"},"guest-author-128":{"file":"head-image-backup-1-e1589778351568.jpg?resize=128,128","width":128,"height":128,"mime_type":"image\/jpeg","source_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/head-image-backup-1-e1589778351568.jpg?w=128&h=128&crop=1"},"concierge-thumb":{"file":"head-image-backup-1-e1589778351568.jpg?resize=50,27","width":50,"height":27,"mime_type":"image\/jpeg","source_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/head-image-backup-1-e1589778351568.jpg?w=50"},"full":{"file":"head-image-backup-1-e1589778351568.jpg","width":783,"height":418,"mime_type":"image\/jpeg","source_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/head-image-backup-1-e1589778351568.jpg"}},"image_meta":{"aperture":"0","credit":"","camera":"","caption":"","created_timestamp":"0","copyright":"","focal_length":"0","iso":"0","shutter_speed":"0","title":"","orientation":"0","keywords":[]},"filesize":64823},"source_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/head-image-backup-1-e1589778351568.jpg","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/media\/1989982"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/media"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/types\/attachment"}],"replies":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/comments?post=1989982"}],"author":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/tc\/v1\/users\/133574232"}]}}],"wp:term":[[{"id":449557111,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/asia\/","name":"Asia","slug":"asia","taxonomy":"category","parent":0,"rapidData":{"pt":"","pct":""},"submenu_categories":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/tec :[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/24435"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=24435"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=24435"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=24435"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=24435"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":38616,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/smartphones\/","name":"smartphones","slug":"smartphones","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/38616"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=38616"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=38616"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=38616"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=38616"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":30684,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/telecommunications\/","name":"telecommunications","slug":"telecommunications","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/30684"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=30684"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=30684"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=30684"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=30684"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":44433,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/vodafone\/","name":"vodafone","slug":"vodafone","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/44433"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=44433"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=44433"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=44433"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=44433"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[]]}},{"id":1989834,"date":"2020-05-17T19:29:07","date_gmt":"2020-05-18T02:29:07","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=1989834"},"modified":"2020-05-17T19:43:02","modified_gmt":"2020-05-18T02:43:02","slug":"fitbits-rival-amazfit-transparent-reusable-mask","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/05\/17\/fitbits-rival-amazfit-transparent-reusable-mask\/","title":{"rendered":"Fitbit&#8217;s Chinese rival Amazfit mulls a transparent, self-disinfecting mask"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">The COVID-19 pandemic has ushered in a wave of Chinese companies with manufacturing operations to produce virus-fighting equipment: Shenzhen-based electric vehicle giant BYD quickly moved to <a href=\"https:\/\/en.byd.com\/news-posts\/byd-opens-worlds-largest-face-mask-manufacturing-plant\/\">launch what it claims to be the world&#8217;s largest mask plant<\/a>; Hangzhou-based voice intelligence startup Rokid is <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/04\/16\/chinese-startup-rokid-pitches-covid-19-detection-glasses-in-u-s\/\">making thermal imaging glasses<\/a>\u00a0targeted at the US market; and many more.<\/p>\n<p>The latest of such efforts comes from <a class=\"crunchbase-link\" href=\"https:\/\/crunchbase.com\/organization\/huami\" target=\"_blank\" data-type=\"organization\" data-entity=\"huami\">Huami, <span class=\"crunchbase-tooltip-indicator\"><\/span><\/a> the NASDAQ-listed wearables startup that makes <a class=\"crunchbase-link\" href=\"https:\/\/crunchbase.com\/organization\/xiaomi\" target=\"_blank\" data-type=\"organization\" data-entity=\"xiaomi\">Xiaomi&#8217;s <span class=\"crunchbase-tooltip-indicator\"><\/span><\/a> Mi Bands and sells its own fitness tracking watches under the Amazfit brand in more than 70 countries. In a phone interview with TechCrunch, the firm said it is developing a see-through plastic mask with built-in ultraviolet lights that can disinfect filters within 10 minutes when connected to a power supply through a USB port. The caveat is that the lights only sanitize the inside of the mask and users still have to clean the outer surface themselves.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_1989956\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption alignnone\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-1989956\" class=\"size-large wp-image-1989956\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/AERI-Concept-X_11.jpg?w=680\" alt=\"\" width=\"680\" height=\"383\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/AERI-Concept-X_11.jpg 3200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/AERI-Concept-X_11.jpg?resize=150,84 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/AERI-Concept-X_11.jpg?resize=300,169 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/AERI-Concept-X_11.jpg?resize=768,432 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/AERI-Concept-X_11.jpg?resize=680,383 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/AERI-Concept-X_11.jpg?resize=1536,864 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/AERI-Concept-X_11.jpg?resize=2048,1152 2048w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/AERI-Concept-X_11.jpg?resize=50,28 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-1989956\" class=\"wp-caption-text\">The Aeri concept comes with built-in ultraviolet lights that can disinfect filters within 10 minutes when connected to a power supply through a USB port.<\/p><\/div><\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>Called Aeri, the mask uses removable filters that are on par with N95 filtration capacity. If the concept materializes, each filter could last up to a month and a half, significantly longer than the average life of surgical masks and N95 respirators. The modular design allows for customized accessories such as a fan for breathable comfort, hence the mask&#8217;s name Aeri, a homophone of &#8220;airy&#8221;.<\/p>\n<p>Aeri started from the premise that wearing masks could thwart the increasingly common adoption of facial recognition. That said, imaging companies have been working on biometric upgrades to allow analyses of other facial features such as irises or the tip of noses.<\/p>\n<p>Aeri might still have a market appeal though, argued Pengtao Yu, vice president of industrial design at Huami. &#8220;Whether people need to unlock their phones or not, they want to see each other&#8217;s faces at social occasions,&#8221; said Yu, the California-based Chinese designer who had served clients including Nest Labs, Roku, <a class=\"crunchbase-link\" href=\"https:\/\/crunchbase.com\/organization\/gopro\" target=\"_blank\" data-type=\"organization\" data-entity=\"gopro\">GoPro <span class=\"crunchbase-tooltip-indicator\"><\/span><\/a> and Huawei prior to joining Huami.<\/p>\n<p>Huami&#8217;s U.S. operation, which focuses on research and development, opened in 2014 and now counts a dozen of employees.<\/p>\n<p>Many companies turning to pandemic-fighting manufacturing have taken a hit from their core business, but Huami has managed to stay afloat. Its <a href=\"https:\/\/www.prnewswire.com\/news-releases\/huami-corporation-reports-first-quarter-2020-unaudited-financial-results-301057438.html\">Q1<\/a> revenue was up 36% year-over-year to hit $154 million, although net income decreased to $2.7 million from $10.6 million. Its stocks have been declining, however, sliding from a high point of $16 in January to around $10 in mid-May.<\/p>\n<p>Huami is in the process of prototyping the Aeri masks. In Shenzhen, which houses the wearables company&#8217;s headquarters, the development cycle for hardware products &#8212; from ideation to market rollout &#8212; takes as short as 6-12 months thanks to the city&#8217;s rich supply chain resources, said Yu.<\/p>\n<p>Huami hasn&#8217;t priced Aeri at this early stage, but Yu admitted that the masks are targeting the &#8220;mass consumer market&#8221; around the world, not only for protection against viruses but also everyday air pollution, rather than appealing to medical workers. Given Huami&#8217;s history of making wearables at thin margins, it won&#8217;t be surprising that Aeri will be competitively priced.<\/p>\n<p>The Aeri project is part of Huami&#8217;s pivot to enter the general health sector beyond pure fitness monitoring. The company has recently teamed up with a laboratory led by Dr. Zhong Nanshan, the public face of China&#8217;s fight against COVID-19, to track respiratory diseases using wearables. It&#8217;s also in talks with the German public health authority to collaborate on a smartwatch-powered virus monitoring app, the company told TechCrunch.<\/p>\n<p><audio style=\"display: none;\" controls=\"controls\"><\/audio><\/p>\n<p><audio style=\"display: none;\" controls=\"controls\"><\/audio><\/p>\n<p><audio style=\"display: none;\" controls=\"controls\"><\/audio><\/p>\n<p><audio style=\"display: none;\" controls=\"controls\"><\/audio><\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>The COVID-19 pandemic has ushered in a wave of Chinese companies with manufacturing operations to produce virus-fighting equipment: Shenzhen-based electric vehicle giant BYD quickly moved to launch what it claims to be the world&#8217;s largest mask plant; Hangzhou-based voice intelligence startup Rokid is making thermal imaging glasses\u00a0targeted at the US market; and many more. The :"Apple begins reopening some stores with temperature checks and other safeguards in place"},"content":{"rendered":"<p class=\"p1\"><span class=\"s1\">In mid-March, Apple closed all of its stores outside of China \u201cuntil further notice.\u201d It was a sweeping \u2014 but necessary \u2014 move for a world facing down a growing pandemic. In a statement issued today until the title, <a href=\"https:\/\/www.apple.com\/store-opening-letter\/\">\u201cTo our Customers,\u201d<\/a> Retail SVP Deirdre O\u2019Brien offered insight into the company\u2019s plans to reopen locations.<\/span><\/p>\n<p class=\"p1\"><span class=\"s1\">Nearly 100 stores have already resumed services, according to O\u2019Brien \u2014 though the famously open retail spaces are taking on a new look in the face of the highly contagious novel coronavirus. \u201cIn every store, we&#8217;re focused on limiting occupancy and giving everybody lots of room, and renewing our focus on one\u2011on\u2011one, personalized service at the Genius Bar and throughout\u00a0the\u00a0store,\u201d she writes. <\/span><\/p>\n<p class=\"p1\"><span class=\"s1\">A spokesperson for the company adds, \u201cNext week we\u2019ll continue our very gradual and thoughtful reopening of US stores, adding more than 25 locations in seven states. While we know many customers are eager for their local store to reopen, our commitment is to reopen our stores when we are confident the environment is safe. We miss our customers and look forward to seeing them again soon.\u201d<\/span><\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"brcLkjECbk\"><p id=\"speakable-summary\"><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/03\/17\/apple-now-says-its-retail-stores-are-closed-until-further-notice\/\">Apple now says its retail stores are closed &#8216;until further notice&#8217;<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe title=\"&#8220;Apple now says its retail stores are closed &#8216;until further notice&#8217;&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/03\/17\/apple-now-says-its-retail-stores-are-closed-until-further-notice\/embed\/#?secret=brcLkjECbk\" data-secret=\"brcLkjECbk\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p class=\"p1\"><span class=\"s1\">As seen in the above image, face covers will be required for both employees and customers alike \u2014 already a legal requirement in many locales. More unusual for many retail establishments is the addition of temperature checks now conducted at the store\u2019s entrance, coupled with posted health questions. Apple has also instituted deeper cleaning on all surfaces, including display products. <\/span><\/p>\n<p class=\"p1\"><span class=\"s1\">That last point is an important one, given how much of the company\u2019s store layout revolves around hands-on products. Curb-side pick and drop off have been added, as well, for those who understandably would like to avoid the in-person experience.<\/span><\/p>\n<p class=\"p1\"><span class=\"s1\">As for when each location reopens, Apple says it\u2019s monitoring health trends and local\/national guidance to determine the timeframe. You can check your local store&#8217;s status <a href=\"https:\/\/www.apple.com\/retail\/\">here<\/a>. And as the conversation of secondary waves begin to become a reality in many areas, O\u2019Brien says the company will close stores down again, if necessary. \u201cThese are not decisions we rush into,\u201d she writes, \u201cand a store opening in no way means that we won&#8217;t take the preventative step of closing it again should local conditions warrant.\u201d<\/span><\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>In mid-March, Apple closed all of its stores outside of China \u201cuntil further notice.\u201d It was a sweeping \u2014 but necessary \u2014 move for a world facing down a growing pandemic. In a statement issued today until the title, \u201cTo our Customers,\u201d Retail SVP Deirdre O\u2019Brien offered insight into the company\u2019s plans to reopen locations. p:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=291"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=291"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=291"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=291"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":55497,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/apple-store\/","name":"apple store","slug":"apple-store","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/55497"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=55497"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=55497"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=55497"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=55497"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":576734528,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/coronavirus\/","name":"coronavirus","slug":"coronavirus","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576734528"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576734528"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576734528"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576734528"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576734528"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":576740177,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/covid-19\/","name":"COVID-19","slug":"covid-19","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576740177"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576740177"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576740177"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576740177"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576740177"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[]]}},{"id":1989909,"date":"2020-05-17T16:00:11","date_gmt":"2020-05-17T23:00:11","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=1989909"},"modified":"2020-05-17T15:31:47","modified_gmt":"2020-05-17T22:31:47","slug":"why-are-people-who-cite-videos-always-wrong","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/05\/17\/why-are-people-who-cite-videos-always-wrong\/","title":{"rendered":"Why are people who cite videos always wrong?"},"content":{"rendered":"<div class=\"article__contributor-byline-wrapper\">\n<div class=\"article__contributor-byline\">\n\t<div class=\"contributor-byline__contributor\">\n\t\t<div class=\"byline__author\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<span class=\"byline__author-name\">Jon Evans<\/span>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<span class=\"byline__author-title\" style=\"display: block;\">Contributor<\/span>\n\t\t<\/div>\n\n\t\t\t<\/div>\n\n\t\t<div class=\"contributor-byline__bio\">\n\t\tJon Evans is the CTO of the engineering consultancy HappyFunCorp; the award-winning author of six novels, one graphic novel, and a book of travel writing; and TechCrunch's weekend columnist since 2010.\t<\/div>\n\t\n\t\t<div class=\"contributor-byline__more-articles\">\n\t\t<span class=\"more-articles-title\">More posts by this contributor<\/span>\n\t\t<ul class=\"more-articles-list\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/05\/10\/seven-viral-futures\/\">Seven viral futures<\/a><\/li>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/05\/03\/let-housing-rise-from-the-empty-offices-and-malls\/\">Let housing rise from the empty offices and malls<\/a><\/li>\n\t\t\t\t\t<\/ul>\n\t<\/div>\n\t<\/div>\n<\/div><p id=\"speakable-summary\">I&#8217;m sure you&#8217;ve experienced it too. Some kind of discussion &#8212; perhaps a dispute, perhaps just a friendly exchange of ideas &#8212; arises online. People regurgitate what they know, or what they think they know. A few admirable souls even include links to sources. Those people tend to be more correct &#8212;<\/p>\n<p>&#8212; unless their citation is a link to a video longer than a couple of minutes &#8230; in which case they are, almost invariably, completely wrong, and often far more wrong than even the wrongest of the people who cited nothing at all.<\/p>\n<p>There&#8217;s no intrinsic reason for this. Video is as good a medium as any for supporting a viewpoint. Longer videos should if anything provide better material support. So why are such online citations always, almost without exception, made of ridiculously brittle clay?<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>Please note that I&#8217;m referring to discussions which involve some objective truth. De gustibus non est disputandum and all that, and videos are often one of the best ways to support subjective opinion. (&#8220;<a href=\"https:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/Screen_Junkies#Honest_Trailers\">Honest Trailers<\/a>&#8221; might be my favorite YouTube series ever.) And a sixty-second clip to illustrate a particular concrete point? Often easily worth a thousand words.<\/p>\n<p>But when you&#8217;re linked to something ten minutes longer or more, especially with an exhortation to &#8220;watch the whole thing!&#8221;, you already know you&#8217;re entering the land of illogic and unreason.<\/p>\n<p>Is this because videos are a &#8220;hot&#8221; medium, connected straight(er) to our limbic system, and therefore unusually well suited to covering up half-truths and specious arguments? Are people instinctively more inclined to give the benefit of any doubt to an impassioned or confident person or voice, compared the benefit of the doubt, compared to the written word?<\/p>\n<p>Or is this a correlation-not-causation thing? Is someone who was willing to sit through a long video, almost by definition, someone who&#8217;s already internalized its arguments rather than think critically about them? And\/or, someone who favors information absorption via long videos because they have a relatively low level of written literacy, and therefore have limited critical thinking skills full stop?<\/p>\n<p>Or do people who link to long videos know that essentially no one has enough time and interest to actually wade their way through them? Are they just using their &#8220;citation&#8221; as a bad-faith smokescreen to pretend that they&#8217;re serious thinkers who have done their research? That strikes me as extremely plausible, a lot of the time. Some of the watch-this-half-hour-video people seem to be operating in good faith, though, just &#8230; misguided.<\/p>\n<p>It&#8217;s not an inherent law of the universe that if you have to cite a 30-minute video, it means you don&#8217;t actually have any cogent arguments. But it does seem to be a law of the Internet. Perhaps that&#8217;s for the best, though; it means when the deepfakes arrive en masse, we &#8212; or, at least, the critical thinkers among us &#8212; will be suspicious already. Let&#8217;s hope automatic skepticism of videos spreads before then.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Jon Evans Contributor Jon Evans is the CTO of the engineering consultancy HappyFunCorp; the award-winning author of six novels, one graphic novel, and a book of travel writing; and TechCrunch&#8217;s weekend columnist since 2010. More posts by this contributor Seven viral futures Let housing rise from the empty offices and malls I&#8217;m sure you&#8217;ve experienced n\/","name":"Column","slug":"column","taxonomy":"category","parent":0,"rapidData":{"pt":"","pct":""},"submenu_categories":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories\/25515"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/category"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?categories=25515"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?categories=25515"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?categories=25515"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":352,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/opinion\/","name":"Opinion","slug":"opinion","taxonomy":"category","parent":0,"rapidData":{"pt":"","pct":""},"submenu_categories":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories\/352"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/category"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?categories=352"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?categories=352"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?categories=352"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":17396,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tc\/","name":"TC","slug":"tc","taxonomy":"category","parent":0,"rapidData":{"pt":"","pct":""},"submenu_categories":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories\/17396"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/category"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?categories=17396"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?categories=17396"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?categories=17396"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":1989756,"date":"2020-05-17T14:23:03","date_gmt":"2020-05-17T21:23:03","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=1989756"},"modified":"2020-05-17T11:36:11","modified_gmt":"2020-05-17T18:36:11","slug":"tech-for-good-during-covid-19-snorkels-thank-you-notes-and-headspace","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/05\/17\/tech-for-good-during-covid-19-snorkels-thank-you-notes-and-headspace\/","title":{"rendered":"Tech for good during COVID-19: Snorkels, thank you notes, and Headspace"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Everyone is living a different pandemic right now. Your relationship with shelter-in-place mandates and social distancing can look wildly different depending on your profession, age, health and, often, privilege. It\u2019s why a week of monotony for some of us might mean a week of madness for others. The best we can do, as exhaustion and Zoom fatigue sets in, is try to be patient, kind and thoughtful.<\/p>\n<p>That\u2019s why this week we are showcasing a number of different tech initiatives trying to tackle the stresses of specific groups, from students to nurses. Let\u2019s get into it.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Help for interns. <\/strong>Major League Hacking, an edtech company that focuses on engineers, is partnering with Github to launch a summer program that is an <a href=\"https:\/\/fellowship.mlh.io\/\">alternative to internships<\/a>. Students will spend 12 weeks working on open source projects, and get feedback from professional engineers. The students will be paid $1,000 per month.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Healthcare worker family support. <\/strong><a href=\"https:\/\/junilearning.com\/\">Juni Learning<\/a>, an online tutoring startup, launched a new initiative to support struggling families of healthcare workers. The platform is giving away $150,000 in credits for its Juni Team product. The Juni Team connects students to small groups with a live instructor to work on STEM projects. \u201cWe are hopeful that the Team Sessions will allow Juni to be able to support a greater number of students who may not necessarily need 1:1 instruction, but rather, just crave being back in a structured learning environment with new or existing friends,\u201d the CEO Vivian Shen said in <a href=\"https:\/\/medium.com\/@vivianmshen\/doing-our-part-to-help-families-in-need-150k-in-free-tuition-812a7bc8db57\">a Medium post<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Health-friendly snorkels. <\/strong>Doctors at hospitals all around the country teamed up to work with Google project engineers and academics from Columbia, MIT, Harvard and more to make snorkel masks into protective PPE gear for doctors. The masks are not meant to replace FDA-approved N95s, but instead can take the place of disposable N95s. Researchers took snorkels, printed breathing filters using 3-D technology and are giving the washable and <a href=\"https:\/\/maskson.org\/\">reusable product to healthcare workers<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p><strong>A free social media manager. <\/strong>Unemployment in 2020 is<a href=\"https:\/\/www.cbsnews.com\/news\/unemployment-rate-could-hit-25-percent-goldman-sachs-predicts\/\"> rivaling the Great Depression<\/a>, leaving over 30 million Americans without work. That\u2019s why <a href=\"http:\/\/justloop.it\/\">SalesLoop<\/a> is giving its platform, which manages social media platforms on LinkedIn, Twitter, and e-mail, for free to job seekers for three months. \u201cThe aim here is to help people who want to grow their network and be proactive about reaching out to potential hiring managers, to do so for free. Normally, our biggest customer base are recruiters \u2013 so this is sort of the reverse effect that we\u2019re seeing now,\u201d said John Fennessy, a director at the company.<\/p>\n<p><strong>On-demand volunteers. <\/strong><a href=\"https:\/\/www.monami.io\/\">Mon Ami<\/a> is collaborating with the city of San Francisco and Los Angeles to connect thousands of available volunteers free to do critical errands with people in need, from seniors living alone to at-risk adults and children. The volunteer management platform is backed by Cowboy Ventures, and traditionally connected college students with the elderly. During COVID-19, Mon Ami has set up volunteers one-on-one with people in need, and serves as a central hub to help cities, NGOs target more seamlessly.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Firefly tries to help.\u00a0<\/strong>Ridesharing advertising company <a href=\"https:\/\/www.fireflyon.com\/\">Firefly<\/a> is providing an in-car plastic protective sheet-film to its drivers at no cost to help reduce the risk of COVID-19 exposure. The initiative is starting in San Francisco and is aimed to help independent rideshare drivers that drive for a ride-hailing company like Uber or Lyft.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Sound on.\u00a0<\/strong><a href=\"https:\/\/www.shure.com\/en-US\">Shure<\/a>, a Chicago-based headphone startup, has donated $79,000 worth of earphones to Chicago Public Schools to support students and teachers with online learning.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Thank you notes for healthcare workers. <\/strong>Depending on where you live, when 7 p.m. rolls around your street might be filled with cheers in solitude with your local healthcare workers. But, for those workers on shift, the cheers might be muffled from the sheer stress happening within hospitals. <a href=\"https:\/\/www.6ftcloser.com\/\">6FTCloser<\/a> lets anybody send a quick, personalized video at no cost to frontline workers, for them to watch on their time. The platform was founded mid-April and over 1,000 frontline workers in 40 states across America and more than nine countries have received personalized videos thanks to this service.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Headspace for a year. <\/strong>Unemployed Americans are <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/05\/14\/unemployed-americans-can-get-a-free-year-of-headspace\/\">eligible for a year of Headspace<\/a>, a digital meditation service. The mobile app startup also offered its meditation content to any and all frontline workers. \u201cWhile meditation and mindfulness can\u2019t change our circumstances in life, it can help us change our perspective on those circumstances. And, now more than ever, that\u2019s an incredibly powerful skill to learn,\u201d said Rich Pierson, the CEO of Headspace, <a href=\"https:\/\/www.businesswire.com\/news\/home\/20200514005286\/en\/Headspace-Announces-Free-One-Year-Subscriptions-Unemployed-Americans\">in a release.<\/a><\/p>\n<p><strong>Honorable mention. <\/strong><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/05\/15\/where-to-shop-online-that-isnt-amazon-target-or-walmart\/\">Where to shop that isn\u2019t Amazon, Target or Walmart?<\/a>\u00a0A few of us on the TechCrunch team listed out a couple options to support local businesses versus big corporations. We hope you take our suggestions into consideration!<\/p>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/pages\/covid-19-updates\/\"><img src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/03\/covid-19-footer.png\" \/><\/a><\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Everyone is living a different pandemic right now. Your relationship with shelter-in-place mandates and social distancing can look wildly different depending on your profession, age, health and, often, privilege. It\u2019s why a week of monotony for some of us might mean a week of madness for others. The best we can do, as exhaustion and [{"id":12084652,"name":"Steve Gillmor","url":"","description":"","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/author\/steve-gillmor\/","slug":"steve-gillmor","avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\/\/secure.gravatar.com\/avatar\/e819990a43a5972b40593cdc6896eef9?s=24&d=identicon&r=g","48":"https:\/\/secure.gravatar.com\/avatar\/e819990a43a5972b40593cdc6896eef9?s=48&d=identicon&r=g","96":"https:\/\/secure.gravatar.com\/avatar\/e819990a43a5972b40593cdc6896eef9?s=96&d=identicon&r=g"},"links":{"homepage":"https:\/\/medium.com\/liner-notes","facebook":"http:\/\/www.facebook.com\/salesforce","twitter":"https:\/\/twitter.com\/stevegillmor","linkedin":"https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/in\/stevegillmor","crunchbase":"https:\/\/www.crunchbase.com\/person\/steve-gillmor"},"position":"Contributing Editor","cbDescription":"<p>Steve Gillmor is a technology commentator, editor, and producer in the enterprise technology space. He is Head of Technical Media Strategy at salesforce.com and a TechCrunch contributing editor.<\/p>\n\n<p>Gillmor previously worked with leading musical artists including Paul Butterfield, David Sanborn, and members of The Band after an early career as a record producer and filmmaker with Columbia Records' Firesign Theatre. As personal computers emerged in video and music production tools, Gillmor started contributing to various publications, most notably Byte Magazine, where he was a lead reviewer of development and collaborative platform systems including Visual Basic, Lotus Notes, Microsoft Office, and Windows NT. Subsequently, Gillmor served as a contributing editor at InformationWeek Labs, before joining Fawcette Technical Publications first as Senior Editor and later as Editor in Chief of Enterprise Development Magazine, and then Editor in Chief and Editorial Director of XML and Java Pro Magazines.<\/p>\n\n<p>Gillmor joined InfoWorld Magazine as Test Center Director and back-page columnist. He also served as Editor of eWEEK.com's Messaging &amp; Collaboration Center and OpEd columnist of eWeek's print publication. As  blogging emerged, he wrote the first blogs for Ziff Davis Media, CMP's CRN, and CNet's ZDNet, where he remains a contributing editor. A podcasting pioneer, he developed and hosted the seminal Gillmor Gang podcast with industry notables including Jon Udell, <a href=\"http:\/\/www.crunchbase.com\/person\/Dan-Farber\">Dan Farber<\/a>, <a href=\"http:\/\/www.crunchbase.com\/person\/michael-arrington\">Mike Arrington<\/a>, <a href=\"http:\/\/www.crunchbase.com\/person\/Jason-Calacanis\">Jason Calacanis<\/a>, <a href=\"http:\/\/www.crunchbase.com\/person\/michael-vizard\">Michael Vizard<\/a>, <a href=\"http:\/\/www.crunchbase.com\/person\/doc-searls\">Doc Searls<\/a> and others as regulars. Gillmor has also championed development of industry standards, most notably his role as co-creator of the attention.xml specification and co-founder of the Attention Trust, a non-profit organization to protect user data rights.<\/p>","cbAvatar":"https:\/\/crunchbase-production-res.cloudinary.com\/image\/upload\/v1413830679\/h40ipdoi0xu3i5pahudv.jpg","twitter":"stevegillmor","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/tc\/v1\/users\/12084652"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/tc\/v1\/users"}]}}],"author":[{"id":12084652,"name":"Steve Gillmor","url":"","description":"","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/author\/steve-gillmor\/","slug":"steve-gillmor","avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\/\/secure.gravatar.com\/avatar\/e819990a43a5972b40593cdc6896eef9?s=24&d=identicon&r=g","48":"https:\/\/secure.gravatar.com\/avatar\/e819990a43a5972b40593cdc6896eef9?s=48&d=identicon&r=g","96":"https:\/\/secure.gravatar.com\/avatar\/e819990a43a5972b40593cdc6896eef9?s=96&d=identicon&r=g"},"links":{"homepage":"https:\/\/medium.com\/liner-notes","facebook":"http:\/\/www.facebook.com\/salesforce","twitter":"https:\/\/twitter.com\/stevegillmor","linkedin":"https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/in\/stevegillmor","crunchbase":"https:\/\/www.crunchbase.com\/person\/steve-gillmor"},"position":"Contributing Editor","cbDescription":"<p>Steve Gillmor is a technology commentator, editor, and producer in the enterprise technology space. He is Head of Technical Media Strategy at salesforce.com and a TechCrunch contributing editor.<\/p>\n\n<p>Gillmor previously worked with leading musical artists including Paul Butterfield, David Sanborn, and members of The Band after an early career as a record producer and filmmaker with Columbia Records' Firesign Theatre. As personal computers emerged in video and music production tools, Gillmor started contributing to various publications, most notably Byte Magazine, where he was a lead reviewer of development and collaborative platform systems including Visual Basic, Lotus Notes, Microsoft Office, and Windows NT. Subsequently, Gillmor served as a contributing editor at InformationWeek Labs, before joining Fawcette Technical Publications first as Senior Editor and later as Editor in Chief of Enterprise Development Magazine, and then Editor in Chief and Editorial Director of XML and Java Pro Magazines.<\/p>\n\n<p>Gillmor joined InfoWorld Magazine as Test Center Director and back-page columnist. He also served as Editor of eWEEK.com's Messaging &amp; Collaboration Center and OpEd columnist of eWeek's print publication. As  blogging emerged, he wrote the first blogs for Ziff Davis Media, CMP's CRN, and CNet's ZDNet, where he remains a contributing editor. A podcasting pioneer, he developed and hosted the seminal Gillmor Gang podcast with industry notables including Jon Udell, <a href=\"http:\/\/www.crunchbase.com\/person\/Dan-Farber\">Dan Farber<\/a>, <a href=\"http:\/\/www.crunchbase.com\/person\/michael-arrington\">Mike Arrington<\/a>, <a href=\"http:\/\/www.crunchbase.com\/person\/Jason-Calacanis\">Jason Calacanis<\/a>, <a href=\"http:\/\/www.crunchbase.com\/person\/michael-vizard\">Michael Vizard<\/a>, <a href=\"http:\/\/www.crunchbase.com\/person\/doc-searls\">Doc Searls<\/a> and others as regulars. Gillmor has also championed development of industry standards, most notably his role as co-creator of the attention.xml specification and co-founder of the Attention Trust, a non-profit organization to protect user data the e-commerce shift going to last?"},"content":{"rendered":"<div class=\"article__contributor-byline-wrapper\">\n<div class=\"article__contributor-byline\">\n\t<div class=\"contributor-byline__contributor\">\n\t\t<div class=\"byline__author\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<span class=\"byline__author-name\">Ashwin Ramasamy<\/span>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<span class=\"byline__author-title\" style=\"display: block;\">Contributor<\/span>\n\t\t<\/div>\n\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"contributor__twitter\">\n\t\t\t<a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/Ashwinizer\">\n\t\t\t\t\t<svg class=\"icon icon--twitter icon--white\" viewBox=\"0 0 20 20\" version=\"1.1\" aria-labelledby=\"title\">\n\t\t<title>Share on Twitter<\/title>\n\t\t<path d=\"M20,4c-0.7,0.3-1.5,0.6-2.4,0.7c0.9-0.5,1.5-1.4,1.8-2.3c-0.8,0.5-1.7,0.8-2.6,1C16.1,2.5,15,2,13.8,2c-2.3,0-4.1,1.9-4.1,4.2c0,0.3,0,0.7,0.1,1C6.4,7,3.4,5.4,1.4,2.9C1,3.5,0.8,4.1,0.8,4.9c0,1.4,0.7,2.7,1.8,3.5C2,8.4,1.4,8.2,0.8,7.9v0.1c0,2,1.4,3.7,3.3,4.1c-0.4,0.1-0.7,0.2-1.1,0.2c-0.3,0-0.5,0-0.8-0.1c0.5,1.7,2,2.9,3.8,2.9c-1.4,1.1-3.2,2-5.1,2c-0.3,0-0.7,0-1-0.1c1.8,1.2,4,1.7,6.3,1.7c7.5,0,11.7-6.4,11.7-12V6.1C18.8,5.6,19.4,4.8,20,4z\"\/>\t<\/svg>\n\t\t\t\t<\/a>\n\t\t<\/div>\n\t\t\t<\/div>\n\n\t\t<div class=\"contributor-byline__bio\">\n\t\t<a>Ashwin Ramasamy<\/a> is the co-founder of <a href=\"\/\/pipecandy.com\/\">PipeCandy<\/a>, an online merchant graph company that discovers and analyzes business and consumer perception metrics about D2C brands and e-commerce companies.\t<\/div>\n\t\n\t\t<div class=\"contributor-byline__more-articles\">\n\t\t<span class=\"more-articles-title\">More posts by this contributor<\/span>\n\t\t<ul class=\"more-articles-list\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/03\/05\/will-new-retail-help-d2c-brands-succeed-offline\/\">Will &#8216;New Retail&#8217; help D2C brands succeed offline?<\/a><\/li>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2019\/11\/11\/d2c-companies-deliver-customer-delight-and-simplicity\/\">D2C companies deliver customer delight and simplicity<\/a><\/li>\n\t\t\t\t\t<\/ul>\n\t<\/div>\n\t<\/div>\n<\/div><p id=\"speakable-summary\"><span class=\"featured__span-first-words\">E-commerce is taking<\/span> off faster than ever. In the last couple of weeks, my Twitter timeline has been filled with operators gushing about how the weekends seem like Black Friday, even for non-essential commodities. Change is already here.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"550\" data-dnt=\"true\">\n<p lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">As we help thousands of businesses to move online, our platform is now handling Black Friday level traffic every day! <\/p>\n<p>It won&#39;t be long before traffic has doubled or more.<\/p>\n<p>Our merchants aren&#39;t stopping, neither are we. We need \ud83e\udde0to scale our platform.<a href=\"https:\/\/t.co\/e2JeyjcEeC\">https:\/\/t.co\/e2JeyjcEeC<\/a> <a href=\"https:\/\/t.co\/6lqSrNUCte\">pic.twitter.com\/6lqSrNUCte<\/a><\/p>\n<p>&mdash; Jean-Michel Lemieux (@jmwind) <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/jmwind\/status\/1250816681024331777?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">April 16, 2020<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><script async src=\"https:\/\/platform.twitter.com\/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"><\/script><\/div>\n<p>Looking at the above graph in this Tweet from <a class=\"crunchbase-link\" href=\"https:\/\/crunchbase.com\/organization\/shopify\" target=\"_blank\" data-type=\"organization\" data-entity=\"shopify\">Shopify <span class=\"crunchbase-tooltip-indicator\"><\/span><\/a> CTO Jean-Michel Lemieux \u2014 and the passing, contextless mention of &#8220;Offline2Online&#8221; \u2014 we got curious.<\/p>\n<p>Beyond just the anecdotal evidence, we looked for signs that tell us e-commerce is being adopted at a faster pace. One way to ascertain that is to look at the historical data of how Shopify has been onboarding merchants for the last two years on a monthly basis, and compare that with what happened this year in Q1.<\/p>\n<p>All of these data points come from PipeCandy&#8217;s own data platform that tracks close to 750K+ Shopify merchants with historical data for each:<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_1989692\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-1989692\" class=\"size-large wp-image-1989692\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/newdomainsusingshopify.png?w=680\" alt=\"new domains using shopify each month\" width=\"680\" height=\"398\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/newdomainsusingshopify.png 833w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/newdomainsusingshopify.png?resize=150,88 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/newdomainsusingshopify.png?resize=300,175 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/newdomainsusingshopify.png?resize=768,449 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/newdomainsusingshopify.png?resize=680,398 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/newdomainsusingshopify.png?resize=50,29 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-1989692\" class=\"wp-caption-text\">New domains using Shopify each month<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>While 2020 started on a faster clip than 2018 and 2019, February and March have seen nothing short of jaw-dropping growth in merchant numbers for Shopify. In those two months alone, Shopify seems to have onboarded more merchants than in the whole of 2018.<\/p>\n<p>The softening you see in April is a result of the lag in the way our systems validate and confirm the data and not a slowdown in Shopify per se. The e-commerce embrace is real.<div class=\"extra-crunch-offer-container\"><\/div>","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>In the last couple of weeks, my Twitter timeline has been filled with operators gushing about how the weekends seem like Black Friday weekends, even for non-essential commodities. Change is already here.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":133574325,"featured_media":1989717,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"outcome":"","status":"","crunchbase_tag":0,"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"999dadb3-75b5-307a-bdd6-416675088ed0"},"categories":[25515,11160,576737633,576754162,20429,35394854],"tags":[576734528,576740177,9881,1073403,388845,64435192,698273,80998],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_event":[],"jetpack_featured_media_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/GettyImages-1209315177-e1589580466637.jpg","shortlink":"https:\/\/tcrn.ch\/3bGWSlm","rapidData":{"pt":"","pct":""},"featured":false,"subtitle":"","fundingRound":false,"seoTitle":"","seoDescription":"","premiumContent":true,"premiumCutoffPercent":0.45,"tc_cb_mapping":[{"slug":"shopify","cb_name":"Shopify","cb_slug":"shopify-organization","cb_link":"https:\/\/crunchbase.com\/organization\/shopify"},{"slug":"postmates","cb_name":"Postmates","cb_slug":"postmates-organization","cb_link":"https:\/\/crunchbase.com\/organization\/postmates"}],"associatedEvent":null,"event":null,"authors":[1024676],"hideFeaturedImage":false,"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts\/1989689"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/types\/post"}],"replies":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/comments?post=1989689"}],"version-history":[{"count":5,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts\/1989689\/revisions"}],"predecessor-version":[{"id":1989720,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts\/1989689\/revisions\/1989720"}],"authors":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/guest-authors\/ashwin-ramasamy"}],"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/edit":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.co code","slug":"qr-code","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/698273"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=698273"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=698273"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=698273"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=698273"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":80998,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/shopify\/","name":"Shopify","slug":"shopify","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/80998"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=80998"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=80998"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=80998"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=80998"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[]]}},{"id":1989555,"date":"2020-05-17T08:00:41","date_gmt":"2020-05-17T15:00:41","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=1989555"},"modified":"2020-05-15T15:53:06","modified_gmt":"2020-05-15T22:53:06","slug":"the-great-reset","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/05\/17\/the-great-reset\/","title":{"rendered":"The Great Reset"},"content":{"rendered":"<div class=\"article__contributor-byline-wrapper\">\n<div class=\"article__contributor-byline\">\n\t<div class=\"contributor-byline__contributor\">\n\t\t<div class=\"byline__author\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<span class=\"byline__author-name\">Ann Miura-Ko<\/span>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<span class=\"byline__author-title\" style=\"display: block;\">Contributor<\/span>\n\t\t<\/div>\n\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"contributor__twitter\">\n\t\t\t<a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/annimaniac\">\n\t\t\t\t\t<svg class=\"icon icon--twitter icon--white\" viewBox=\"0 0 20 20\" version=\"1.1\" aria-labelledby=\"title\">\n\t\t<title>Share on Twitter<\/title>\n\t\t<path d=\"M20,4c-0.7,0.3-1.5,0.6-2.4,0.7c0.9-0.5,1.5-1.4,1.8-2.3c-0.8,0.5-1.7,0.8-2.6,1C16.1,2.5,15,2,13.8,2c-2.3,0-4.1,1.9-4.1,4.2c0,0.3,0,0.7,0.1,1C6.4,7,3.4,5.4,1.4,2.9C1,3.5,0.8,4.1,0.8,4.9c0,1.4,0.7,2.7,1.8,3.5C2,8.4,1.4,8.2,0.8,7.9v0.1c0,2,1.4,3.7,3.3,4.1c-0.4,0.1-0.7,0.2-1.1,0.2c-0.3,0-0.5,0-0.8-0.1c0.5,1.7,2,2.9,3.8,2.9c-1.4,1.1-3.2,2-5.1,2c-0.3,0-0.7,0-1-0.1c1.8,1.2,4,1.7,6.3,1.7c7.5,0,11.7-6.4,11.7-12V6.1C18.8,5.6,19.4,4.8,20,4z\"\/>\t<\/svg>\n\t\t\t\t<\/a>\n\t\t<\/div>\n\t\t\t<\/div>\n\n\t\t<div class=\"contributor-byline__bio\">\n\t\tAnn Miura-Ko is a co-founding partner at <a href=\"https:\/\/floodgate.com\/\">Floodgate<\/a>, a seed-stage VC firm. A repeat member of the Forbes Midas List and the New York Times Top 20 Venture Capitalists Worldwide, she earned a PhD in math modeling of cybersecurity at Stanford University.\t<\/div>\n\t\n\t\t<div class=\"contributor-byline__more-articles\">\n\t\t<span class=\"more-articles-title\">More posts by this contributor<\/span>\n\t\t<ul class=\"more-articles-list\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/01\/31\/you-need-a-minimum-viable-company-not-a-minimum-viable-product-2\/\">True product-market fit is a minimum viable company<\/a><\/li>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/01\/31\/you-need-a-minimum-viable-company-not-a-minimum-viable-product\/\">You need a minimum viable company, not a minimum viable product<\/a><\/li>\n\t\t\t\t\t<\/ul>\n\t<\/div>\n\t<\/div>\n<\/div><p id=\"speakable-summary\"><span class=\"featured__span-first-words\">Talk of an economic<\/span> downturn can be frightening, especially one precipitated by a pervasive health crisis. At times, I\u2019m overwhelmed by the images of countless patients on life-support and the near-endless streams of statistics regurgitating bad news.<\/p>\n<p>Having started in venture at the beginning of two recessions, I\u2019ve seen how the startup industry functions during economic trouble. My second day of work at Charles River Ventures was September 11th, 2001. My first project, analyzing the VC industry, propelled the firm to return more than 60% of its fund to investors, going from a $1.2 billion fund to $450 million. In May 2008, Mike Maples and I founded Floodgate in the midst of the Great Recession. We learned that great founders won\u2019t wait for a better economic moment to start a company.<\/p>\n<p>While we are currently embroiled in personal and professional circumstances unimaginable even three months ago, these very challenges will form the basis of incredibly innovative ideas. In order for the world to move forward, we need our greatest minds to imagine a brighter future and create solutions to make it a reality.<\/p>\n<p>When I analyze our society and novel health situation, one thing is certain: COVID-19 is a paradigm-shifting event, creating massively accelerated social and economic change.<\/p>\n<h2>The Great Reset is not just another economic event<\/h2>\n<p>Our current situation is unique. It\u2019s not merely a cyclical economic event, nor is it a standalone health crisis. What we are experiencing is not just an inflection point: it\u2019s a societal phase-change unlike anything we have ever seen. We face an epic choice of how we move forward, and the decisions we make today will shape an entire generation.<\/p>\n<p>Here\u2019s why: COVID-19 is prompting us to reset many of our most fundamental behaviors. These changes are impacting our financial system, with effects visible throughout our homes, businesses and even the concept of \u201cworkplace\u201d itself.<\/p>\n<h2>COVID-19 is pervasive<\/h2>\n<p>As a global pandemic, the virus itself has spread to nearly every country in the world.<\/p>\n<p>Between February 20 and March 26, 100% of the world\u2019s 20 largest economies implemented government-mandated social distancing. Globally, the number of scheduled airline flights is down 64%. In some countries, like Spain and Germany, flight numbers are down by more than 90%.<\/p>\n<p>Since the timeline for lifting government restrictions is unclear \u2014 and even then, scientists are uncertain how the virus will spread \u2014 the question lingers: How long will this go on?<\/p>\n<p>COVID-19\u2019s impact is uncertain, long-term and potentially undulating, affecting every facet of our lives. You can\u2019t simply wait it out with the expectation that industries will rebound. In 2001, September 11 felt pervasive, but its economic impact ultimately stemmed from just one single incident and the resulting fear&#8230; and that one single incident still cost more than three trillion dollars. How much larger will COVID-19 be?<div class=\"extra-crunch-offer-container\"><\/div>","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>We\u2019re entering a new paradigm, and that brings possibilities. Now, founders, is the time to Crunch Live with Julia Hartz of Eventbrite"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><em>Thursday, June 11 at 12:00pm PT \/ 3:00pm ET<\/em><\/p>\n<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Eventbrite CEO and co-founder Julia Hartz is at the center of an unprecedented time for the events world. The publicly-traded company is more popular than ever with hundreds of millions of dollars in revenue, but the global slowdown of in-person event ticketing due to COVID-19 has had a material impact on Eventbrite\u2019s business. We\u2019ll talk with Hartz on how she is leading her company through a crisis and what the future holds for bringing people together. Crunch Live with Alexis Ohanian and Garry Tan of Initialized\u00a0"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><em>Tuesday, June 2 at 11:00am PT \/ 2:00pm ET<\/em><\/p>\n<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Alexis Ohanian, founder and former CEO of Reddit, is an investor with a portfolio that includes Flexport, Ro, and Papa. His Initialized partner, Garry Tan, has an equally impressive portfolio (Instacart and Coinbase, to name a couple) and a background in entrepreneurship (founded Posterous and Posthaven) and spent four years as a partner at Y Combinator. We\u2019ll chat about how they\u2019re advising portfolio companies, what the next 12-24 months look like for early stage startups, and which sectors are piquing their interest right now.<\/p>\n<p><a class=\"button button--green-gradient button--primary\" href=\"http:\/\/techcrunch.com\/subscribe\">Sign up for Extra Crunch to get access<\/a><\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Tuesday, June 2 at 11:00am PT \/ 2:00pm ET Alexis Ohanian, founder and former CEO of Reddit, is an investor with a portfolio that includes Flexport, Ro, and Papa. His Initialized partner, Garry Tan, has an equally impressive portfolio (Instacart and Coinbase, to name a couple) and a background in entrepreneurship (founded Posterous and Posthaven) [&hellip;]<\/p>\n","protected":false},"featured_media":1975917,"parent":0,"menu_order":0,"template":"","tc_event":[576763577],"rapidData":{"pt":"","pct":""},"agenda":{"sessionTypes":[],"sessionData":[{"date":"2 June","sessions":[{"guid":"694305495eb0791fb00bf","start":"11:00 am","end":"12:00 pm","description":"","title":"Extra Crunch Live with Alexis Ohanian and Garry Tan of Initialized\u00a0","videoUrl":"","sessionTypeId":false,"speakers":[],"sponsors":[],"tags":[]}]}]},"bannerImageURL":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/04\/gian-d-359346-unsplash.jpg","bannerTextStyle":"light","description":"The startup world\u00a0is going through yet another evolution. A few years ago, VCs were focused on growth over profitability. Now, making money is just as important, if not more, than sheer growth. And we\u2019re in the midst of a global pandemic, which has brought the economy to a crawl and forced entrepreneurs to rethink both their short and long-term priorities.\n\nStartups want to hear from the voices they trust for guidance on how to navigate this difficult situation. His Initialized partner, Garry Tan, has an equally impressive portfolio (Instacart and Coinbase, to name a couple) and a background in entrepreneurship (founded Posterous and Posthaven) and spent four years as a partner at Y Combinator. Crunch Live with Aaron Levie of Box"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><em>Thursday, May 28 at 12:00pm PT \/ 3:00pm ET<\/em><\/p>\n<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Box CEO Aaron Levie launched his company in 2005 in the quintessential college dorm room. He helped build it into a public company with almost $700 million in revenue. Along the way, he guided his young company through the financial crisis of 2008 and is helping do the same today. Crunch Live with Steve Case and Clara Sieg of Revolution"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><em>Thursday, May 21 at 12:00pm PT \/ 3:00pm ET<\/em><\/p>\n<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Steve Case founded Revolution&nbsp;in 2005 following his departure from AOL, the company he helped found and built into the Internet 1.0 giant. In 2010 Clara Sieg joined the venture firm and helped start Revolution\u2019s San Francisco office. Together, along with the firm\u2019s other partners, Revolution has found success investing inside and out of the Valley,&nbsp;with a focus on companies based outside of the coastal tech hubs.&nbsp;We are going to talk to the pair about how they\u2019re advising their portfolio companies to survive, thrive, and raise in the current climate.<\/p>\n<p><a class=\"button button--green-gradient button--primary\" href=\"http:\/\/techcrunch.com\/subscribe\">Sign up for Extra Crunch to get access<\/a><\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Thursday, May 21 at 12:00pm PT \/ 3:00pm ET Steve Case founded Revolution&nbsp;in 2005 following his departure from AOL, the company he helped found and built into the Internet 1.0 giant. Together, along with the firm\u2019s other partners, Revolution has [&hellip;]<\/p>\n","protected":false},"featured_media":1975917,"parent":0,"menu_order":0,"template":"","tc_event":[576763571],"rapidData":{"pt":"","pct":""},"agenda":{"sessionTypes":[],"sessionData":[{"date":"21 May","sessions":[{"guid":"694305495eb07631b7b03","start":"12:00 pm","end":"1:00 pm","description":"","title":"Extra Crunch Live with Steve Case and Clara Sieg of Revolution","videoUrl":"","sessionTypeId":false,"speakers":[],"sponsors":[],"tags":[]}]}]},"bannerImageURL":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/04\/gian-d-359346-unsplash.jpg","bannerTextStyle":"light","description":"The startup world\u00a0is going through yet another evolution. Most recently Payam was selected to be on the prestigious \u201cForbes 30 under 30\u201d list in 2017 and Capella has been recognized by The New York Times, Bloomberg, and recently Inc magazine as one of the top 25 disruptive companies in the world.<\/p>\n\n<p>Outside of Capella, Payam spends his time thinking about the impact of technology on society, economy, politics, and human behavior. He is an advocate of raising awareness around the volatility of life on earth and the responsibilities of technologists to think proactively about their work and its intended and unintended consequences.<\/p>\n\n<p>Payam holds a business\/management degree from Stanford University and graduated Magna Cum Laude with a BS in Aerospace Engineering from The University of Texas.<\/p>","cbAvatar":"https:\/\/crunchbase-production-res.cloudinary.com\/image\/upload\/ljwsoekel4nbwnyc0unk","company":"Capella Space","featured":0,"name":"Payam Banazadeh","uuid":"f3543d4641ff3b38bfc6be189d602b3a","cb_tag":576736233,"position":"Chief Executive Officer","links":{"crunchbase":"https:\/\/www.crunchbase.com\/person\/payam-banazadeh","twitter":"https:\/\/twitter.com\/payamban","linkedin":"https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/in\/payamban\/"}},{"bio":"<p>Peter Beck is the founder and chief executive of Rocket Lab, a space systems company and the world\u2019s leading dedicated small satellite launch provider. Rocket Lab provides end-to-end mission services, including complete satellite build and launch solutions, that provide rapid, frequent and reliable access to space. Rocket Lab has been launching since May 2017, delivering satellites to orbit for commercial and government customers, including DARPA, NASA, the NRO, the United States Air Force and more. Since founding the business in 2006, Peter has grown Rocket Lab to become a globally recognized industry leader in space and a billion-dollar company employing hundreds of world-class engineers.<\/p>\n\n<p>In addition to creating Electron, the world\u2019s first fully carbon-fibre orbital launch vehicle, Peter also oversaw the development of the world\u2019s first and only private orbital launch range, located on New Zealand's M\u0101hia Peninsula. Bridenstine was elected in 2012 to represent Oklahoma\u2019s First Congressional District in the U.S. House of Representatives, where he served on the Armed Services Committee and the Science, Space and Technology Committee.<\/p>\n\n<p>Bridenstine\u2019s career in federal service began in the U.S. Navy, flying the E-2C Hawkeye off the USS Abraham Lincoln aircraft carrier. It was there that he flew combat missions in Iraq and Afghanistan and accrued most of his 1,900 flight hours and 333 carrier-arrested landings. He later moved to the F-18 Hornet and flew at the Naval Strike and Air Warfare Center, the parent command to TOPGUN.<\/p>\n\n<p>After transitioning from active duty to the U.S. Navy Reserve, Bridenstine returned to Tulsa, Oklahoma, to be the Executive Director of the Tulsa Air and Space Museum &amp; Planetarium.<\/p>\n\n<p>Bridenstine completed a triple major at Rice University, and earned his MBA at Cornell University. Chris was co-founder of Planet Labs, a DCVC company providing unprecedented daily, global mapping of our changing planet from space. As the company\u2019s CTO for 5 years, he took the company from the drawing board to having launched more satellites into space than any other company in history, completely transforming the space industry along the way.<\/p>\n\n<p>Chris was previously a Space Mission Architect at NASA Ames Research Center. After working on a number of traditional spacecraft programs at NASA, Chris co-created Phonesat, a spacecraft built solely out of a regular smartphone. Her third book in the series was launched to space and read on the International Space Station as part of the Story Time from Space program.<\/p>\n\n<p>Emily has given talks about the importance of science literacy, the benefits of space exploration, and women in STEM at places like Google, Pixar, MIT, West Virginia University, Texas Instruments as well as dozens of K-12 schools across the nation. Callahan is Vice President and General Manager of the Commercial Civil Space line of business for Lockheed Martin Space.  In this role, she is responsible for all aspects of execution and growth for Commercial and Civil markets in human and robotic deep space exploration, communications, and weather and remote sensing.
